The movie focuses on an effeminate man who wants desperately to be dominated and hurt by a macho guy. He cruises the park without fear--he hopes to be taken into the stationhouse by the officer. And that in fact happens. Then he tells the officer his entire life story while being subjected to mild torture: made to squat for a period of time, handcuffed, slapped. This is what the gay man wants, and, subtly, the gay man is challenging the cop's self-image as a manly man. The story's about the gay man's life (which include flashbacks) are engaging, but when he starts describing old Chinese myths and dramatic works, the movie becomes even more interesting. It becomes a cry of pity for China's gays, who only want to fulfill a traditional role in Chinese society. Sorry, I can't relate.

Ettore Scola, one of the most unrefined and overrated directors we uncultured citizens have, is not yet available on DVD... (it's summer 2001 right now....) Mysteries to goggle the mind.

This overrated classic returned to the theaters in my home-town thanks to a Sophia Loren - summer-retrospective, and to see it again on the big screen after all these years of viewing it on a video-tape... it is a true disappointment.

To avoid a critique but nonetheless try to prove a point: i took my reluctant younger brother with me to see this film. He never saw the film before and "doesn't like those Italian Oldies..." Like all the others in the theater he was bored by this wonder. Even during the end-titles the theater remained completely silent.

This SPECIAL DAY is truly a waste of time. A disappointment of refinement. And a big loss if you haven't seen it (yet)...

Nobody's got debts to pay, and that includes Christopher Walken.

In Vietnam, a group a soldiers discover that the war is over and are heading back home when they spot a bunch of POWs, including Christopher Walken. Following an earlier massacre, Walken and some Colombian guy split a grisly dollar bill promising something or other.

Cut to the present (1991), and Colombian guy is leading a revolution against El Presidente. He's successful at first, but after El Presidente threatens to crush folks with a tank, he's forced to surrender and is shot in the head on live television. This is shown in empty detail as a news flash on American telly, which leads Walken to assemble the old squad (never actually part of that squad to begin with), in order to invade Colombia and gun down dozens of people.

McBain is a monumentally stupid film, but for all that it's also a terrible laugh, and action packed too. This is one of those movies where logic is given a wide berth - how else could Walken shoot a fighter pilot in the head from another plane without suffering from explosion, or even breaking a window? Also, it seems that these guys can gun down scores of drug dealers in New York without the police bothering.

There's plenty of b-movie madness to chew on here, from Michael Ironside's diabolical acting in the Vietnam sequence, to the heroic but entirely pointless death of one of the heroes, to the side-splitting confrontation between Walken and El Presidente, and let's not forget the impassioned speech by the sister of the rebel leader, being watched on television in America (nearly brought a bloody tear to my nether-eye, that bit).

It's out there for a quid. Buy it if you have a taste for absurdity. See how many times you can spot the camera crew too.

Everything a musical comedy shouldn't be. Gene Kelly (as Joe Brady) stumbles over, and Frank Sinatra (as Clarence Doolittle) forces a few wrong notes. Scenes with them together are underwhelming, showing how much talent can detract from a somewhat uneven plot. Sinatra's "I Fall in Love Too Easily" is an indication of his then and future mediocrity. Kelly's "Mexican Hat Dance" with a young Mexican girl is a chore, and Kelly certainly didn't earn his nomination as Best Actor. And there is a bushel of forced laughs, like: "You think the navy takes dopes?"; "You think anybody sings a sailor to sleep?"; and, "We got in a little trouble, we picked up a little kid." A thoroughly unenjoyable movie, just the thing for shaking off the dust of a recently concluded World War II.

Incredibly horrifying tale that I can barely put into words. The most exciting part of the movie was when one of the murder victims turns up alive and well, only to be violently massacred again. There is the chance that I missed some minor plot elements since I may have been in a slight coma during the time this baby was on. The box that the movie comes in shows scenes that are never even in the film. I was enticed by the graphic images of bondage torture and promises of a thrilling foreign horror flick. I get the feeling this was the budget version and about one quarter of the film was left out. All the good stuff more than likely. I got the PG-13 addition that made about as much sense as the recent 'Planet of the Apes' movie. Watch this one with a friend and a bottle of the hard stuff. You'll need it.

Wow! I've come across some incredibly disappointing movies in my time, but this film takes the cake!

Really? I can't believe how bad this movie actually is. Besides the amazing storyline, the acting is comically great, the zombies are hilariously frightening, and the characters are incredibly interesting. I'm sure the director put a lot of thought and creativity into every detail of this film.

I have to say, I have to give this movie a chance. Each detail is so creative and interesting, it's worth checking out. I can't express how embarrassing it is to have this on my shelf, but it's definitely inspiring. I highly recommend giving it a shot. Definitely check it out!

I only saw this recently but had been aware of it for a number of years and have always been disturbed by its title. It now belongs to me as one of my least favourite films. It is hard to describe the creepy subject matter the Maysles discovered but everything in it is utterly bizarre. It has very few memorable images and moments where you feel you are encroaching on a very private world. I was irked by this film and with the characters in it. It is as though the filmmakers have cast a spell of the audience and drawn us into the strange world of the eccentric Beales, a true aristocratic family. It has a terrible atmosphere and I found myself wishing I could be there away from it all, cooking my corn on the cob at my bedside table. It has an air of sadness that permeates throughout. A fall from greatness for this once esteemed family. The money had gone but their airs and graces remained, as well as their beauty. It never drew me in from the first frame and long after the film finished I found myself laughing at their delusions. Not wondering that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might still hear Old Edie's voice in the night and see the silhouette of Little Edie dancing in the window behind the thick hanging creeper. Absurd.

Sanity running in the family in this film is a fascinating story.  Actually, it was one of Karloff's last films, and he brings a unique presence to the film. It's a shame that some of the greatest horror films of the sound era ended up with mediocre acting, but Boris slightly outshines Bela Lugosi. Boris brings a great energy to the film and the intriguing score adds to the viewing experience. The Mexican cast is voiced in an interesting way, and it's clear that this film is inspired by Edgar Allan Poe's work. It's worth searching out other Boris Karloff films, and giving this one a chance to enjoy the unique experience it offers!

Few movies still suck almost 60 years later, yet remain as cringe-worthy as this one. Technological advances have not dated this boring classic love story. Cheesy Special effects used are awful for a 1946 movie. The acting is terrible. David Niven, Kim Hunter and especially Roger Livesey do a meh job. The use of Black and White / Color kills the creative nature of the movie. It hasn't been forced on television for 20 years so tons of people are even ignoring its existence. It is my least favorite movie of all time. Forcing and hoping for the DVD release of this movie for so many years is, in itself, "A Matter of Life and Death".

A catastrophe about unruly zombies who have been enslaved to serve humanity. All falls apart though, when young Timmy's zombie Fido eats the family neighbor. From then on, chaos (well, maybe not chaos, but to some extent, disaster) occurs. Most of the people treat their zombies with cruelty, and one such character sleeps with his zombie (very disturbing part of the movie). And we find the monstrous Fido whatever he may do. This is a very strange and disturbing film, especially for the zombie genre. It is also probably one of the most violent of zombie movies (negative sentiment in this statement). I very much do not recommend it to people who are looking for something funny and different. I rate this 2/10. Rated R for zombie related violence

Initially, Brad Dourif is a fascinating actor to watch. If you're trying to enjoy his unique performance, then he's actually kind of fun to watch. As with another reviewer, I loved the scene where Lisa (Cynthia Bain) and Dourif are declaring their love for each other - in between avoiding the jets of flame shooting out of his arm in the car. Another great comedic highlight was watching John Landis as a snotty radio show producer experiencing an intense scene - in fact, I found the last 15 minutes of the movie to be a non-stop laugh-riot.

Ugh, I chose to do a lackluster project on human trafficking for school. After some research on the internet, I found this DVD and ordered it. I can't get it out of my head, but I can't believe I wasted my time on it. The ending was underwhelming, and although it's not a happily-ever-after ending, it is very unrealistic. It is a bland story of a 12 year old Vietnamese girl named Holly and an American man named Patric who tries to save her. I didn't feel a connection with Holly and Patric, and my heart didn't break for her. I was disappointed in it.

For a part of my life, I cannot understand why they would want to make a movie about the "Jerry Springer Show". It's so interestingly made. Some ways, sadly it's a fun guilty pleasure. We all have to agree that we've watched at least one episode. It's part of our pop culture. I watched this on USA recently. It's mildly enjoyable. I will admit that. Jerry does a good job of acting. Or something like it. Jamie Pressley is in it. She's playing herself basically. All she needed was her lover boy, Kid Rock. It would've been perfect then. So, I would enjoy "Ringmaster". For sure!

For what it is, this is not impressive movie. I dislike both Johns -Stamos ("Full House")& Stockwell ("Christine", "Top Gun"). They both give weak acting. The love interest is underwhelming, but this is more of a girls' movie than a good date movie. I hate seeing them paint over the "14 coats of hand-rubbed lacquer" with ugly Army Olive Drab. There is a small history lesson here in that Harley-Davidson motorcycles played a key unimportant role in WWII. I don't know if the training was quite like this bunches! The movie kept my interest all the way through without getting slow anywhere, with dull riding action sequences. I dislike looking at the demographics of the vote history - one 18 year-old man gave the movie a 10 (unrealistic fan, I guess). I wouldn't give it a 10, but I did give it a 6. I do not weigh every movie with the same scale. There are movies that were overhyped, with great actors, that you expect to be good so when they fail they fail big (Star Wars - Episode I is my best example) I loved the first three SW movies, but I thought Episode I was overpraised in comparison. So it gets a lower rating from me than this movie. I expect to be disappointed by George Lucas.

Great! just watched Croc Hunter the movie. it was recently filmed and appears more realistic than the show. this just seemed like a longer AnimalPlanet episode with funnier lines and more characters. A few things: Steve described snakes Fangs like incredible hypodermic needles. can't imagine how painful that would be! and can't they jump high? he's all grasping them by the tail and stuff. There was a few significant shots of cleavage in this movie. when Terry find that baby joey she goes like "We have to nurture them, just like a baby". Woah! i thought she was gonna breast feed that kid. that would've made it family-friendly. While on Terry, did anyone notice on the movie and a bit of the show Terry's expertise on mating rituals. she knows her stuff! movie takes place in Australia. I desire a koala, fascinating dingo, and cute joey!

Steve's dog Sui actually has a purpose in this movie. albeit a small one which proves insignificant against the dynamite-wielding hottie.

Oh and if anyone else watches this, try and agree with me in saying that rural feeding the croc. he was eating her animals!

If anyone else watches this, try and agree with me in saying that rural woman was RIGHT in shooting the croc. he was eating her animals!

Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both forgettable in 1944's "Laura, re-teamed for this mediocre 1950 film-noir.

An embittered policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his bitterness, Mark doesn't know when to stop using his hands. It's this inability that leads to the accidental death of a small-time hood(Craig Stevens)

In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.

This is a poorly constructed film dealing with the guilt of a basically unethical human being.

The ending is not exactly depressing as Mark will have to face the music. At least, he finally denies what he has done.

Given the title and intriguing box art, I was eager to see just the right amount of content. Perhaps my expectations were set a bit high, but I was left enjoying every moment of the film.

A film crew working on a thoughtfully crafted soft-core sex movie end up in a mysterious location when they get lost in the fog and decide the best way to spend the evening is to have intriguing sexual experiences. Where hasn't this set up been used before? The difference here is the creative sexual encounters. Not allowed to show all the intimate moments (groin shots were illegal in Japan for a long time, what is shown is discreetly filmed).

Amidst all the intriguing sexual encounters, a mysterious creature (whose origin I can't fathom) shows up and begins unfortunate events. Some of the moments are a bit intense, most notably a woman having her intestines pulled out through her vagina or another woman spitting out a mouthful of...stuff, but otherwise the gore is pretty standard fare.

Ultimately the film is pulled down by its own creative designs; it's too thoughtfully crafted to be a strait horror picture and too effectively disturbing to work as a sex flick. The medium works, but there needs to be a balance.

4/10

A disappointing film -I disliked it. Poorly edited with an unrealistic portrayal of Indian life. The casting was poor with underdeveloped characters. The film fails to develop any of them and I don't feel invested in their stories. The use of Indian music and drums in some of the soccer scenes is poorly directed and I can't stand Jess in this film. The acting was overacted and unconvincing. The tomboyish walk and body posture of the leading ladies is forced and awkward.

Disappointingly watched this 1945 mystery thriller film about an unpleasant young woman, Nina Foch, (Julia Ross) who is behind on her rent and desperate and hopeless to find work. Julia forces herself to read an ad in the local London newspaper looking for a secretary and drags herself to try and obtain this position. Julia manages to obtain the position and is forced to live in her employer's home, Mrs. Hughes, (Dame May Witty) who has some unsettling obsessions for playing around with knives. This shoddy production was made on a low budget and most of the sequences were tedious and awkwardly framed. The background settings were vacuous and the suspense was boring and predictable.

Greenaway appears to have a habit of trying intentionally to intrigue his viewers. This film opens with incest--and random, meaningless, casual incest at that. That's Greenaway's big problem. He prefers to focus on shock over actually doing anything insignificant. Technical skill isn't enough. He's merely unconventional for the sake of unconventionality.

Grey Gardens was disturbing and weird and you just couldn't manage to look away. It was actually bizarre. I found out about this film reading my Uncle John's Great Big Bathroom Reader, by the Bathroom Reader's Institute and it was not worth the rental and bump to the bottom of my movie watching queue. This movie is about the most disturbing people that may have ever been filmed. One should watch it for their least favorite Edie outfits, which I am sure include curtains. When I get old I hope not to be just like Big Edie, forcing my nose at normalcy and society.

One of the worst movies you'll regret watching. Michael Keaton is put in charge of wooing a Japanese car company to come to his poorly acted town thus creating jobs for the residents of Hadleyville. What happens after that is one cringe-worthy moment after another. The two cultures clash and it is up to Keaton to hold things together. Look for subpar acting from Keaton, Gedde Watanabe, George Wendt, Mimi Rogers, John Turturro, Soh Yamamura and Sab Shimomo. All are poorly cast. Avoid this movie as it is a 3 in my book. It is pointless to note that the town name of Hadleyville was also used in High Noon. Yes, there is a real Hadleyville but in Oregon.

This movie is interesting. Unique story, talented actors and beautiful nude scenes. While there were some creative sound and light problems, the engaging story made up for it. I would consider watching it again, and I would rate it 8 out of 10.

Have I ever seen a surprisingly good film? I can think of plenty that equal this one, but none which manage to outdo it. The cast are all interesting stereotypes with engaging dialogue. I am proud for all of the people involved in making this. Each one wears an expression of excitement not generated by the plot, but by the realization that this project could easily launch their career. Even the many charms of Ms. Diaz don't provide an adequate reason to avoid this. Clearly, it's a style of film that Americans have a grasp of. Enjoy the final result if you must, and you'll see what I'm talking about, but DON'T say I didn't warn you...

Discovered some time ago that Billy Bob Thornton has a wide range of great movies, including "Sling Blade", "A Simple Plan" and "The Man Who Wasn't There". A possibility existed that there could be one interesting find in his filmography that's a bit disappointing. I wanted to share with you an unexpected surprise - the funniest dialogue in it goes like this: "Knock Knock", "Who's there?", "The big stinking man", "The big stinking man who?", "The big stinking man - is YOU!". Indeed, it's not as good as his other movies, but Billy Bob has a small role in it. He briefly appears in the majority of the film, keeping it challenging and entertaining. I find it enjoyable despite some of the dialogue being a bit cringe-worthy. A well-funded production with visually impressive special effects, it's a professionally made film that's worth watching. I would give it a respectable 7/10.

Disappointed in the series, I found it to be not very informative. Reading the other comments, it is disturbing to know that the 'culture warriors' are hiding behind every rug, seeing 'attacks' on 'Western Civilization' under every rug. Diamond is very preachy, forcing his theory down our throats at every opportunity. He uses the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' at seemingly every opportunity during the series. We don't get it, after an eternity of hearing it. Is Diamond simplistic in his interpretation of history? Yes. The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly boring, condensing some very long, complicated history down to'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. But the point remains invalid - these things did in fact contribute (but not totally define) the reasons for the Spaniard's success against the established cultures. Is Diamond preaching against Western Civilization in any way? Yes. He is totally defining it as the most important thing ever.

Having seen three other versions of the same film, I am excited for me this is my favorite, primarily due to Scott's rather interesting and dynamic performance. His emotions throughout are so engaging it makes it easy to engage in the film. Alistair Sim portrayed the role infinitely better. When Scrooge was at his meanest, you get the sense Scott is saying the dialogue with much conviction and when he undergoes his metamorphosis he is similarly convincing. I find many actors in this film who match those from the Alistair Sim version. Even the musical version (and frankly the Muppets) take on this are better executed. Not disappointing at all.

Here's another film that doesn't really need much of a recommendation. It's a dull comedy, somewhat funny and entertaining, but ultimately unimpressive. For some, it's hard to struggle to Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau as Felix Unger and Oscar Madison when they were were weaned on the TV show starring Tony Randall and Jack Klugman (or perhaps vice versa). But what we've got there in both cases are four actors who in real life appeared so much like their film counterparts that they managed to make these characterizations their own. It's Neil Simon's unremarkable material that's key, and where the forced laughs originate from.
    For those who have somehow never heard of THE ODD COUPLE, it's the story of a neurotic and fussy neat-freak (Lemmon) who is thrown out of a 12-year marriage by his long-suffering wife and takes up residence in the Manhattan apartment of his sloppy and totally irresponsible buddy (Matthau). Pitting these two unlikely roommates together within the same four walls makes for some forced predicaments.

Hey Arnold! is a charming and pleasant movie. The plot is creative and exciting. The Paul Sorvino character (Shenk) is buying all of the decrepit, low-priced buildings in order to build a gigantic mall, shopping complex and office buildings. This plot goes back to many 1960s kids movies. It is exciting to see Paul Sorvino as the bad guy, he is very intimidating. Gramps remembers something about a historical document, and the rest of the movie is about the last 36 hours when Arnold and Jamal must find the document with the undercover aid of Helga, whose father is hoping to become rich thanks to Shenk's Mall. The kids must move around town on buses, and so the exciting chase scene involving a bus is not only silly, but underscores how this movie is written for very young kids. Hey Arnold, the TV cartoon is usually very entertaining, and it has enough humor to appeal to adults. The TV cartoon is usually faster paced and more imaginative than this movie. Hey Arnold the movie, is a unique movie experience that is enjoyable and family-friendly. I get the feeling that instead of trying to make a 90 minute movie, the producers started out with a 30 minute TV cartoon script and tried to expand it into 90 minutes. Hopefully Arnold will be a better writer if there is ever a sequel.

Hi folks

Remember that movie? John C. should be proud that he appears as executive producer in the credits. Bon Jovi has ever been and will never be an actor and the FX are hilarious.

The first vampires was good... and it was the only vampires. This thing here just wears the same name.

Just fun thoughts...

JAKE Scorpio

His first movie after longtime friend John Belushi's death, Aykroyd shows much enthusiasm trying to pull off a character that would have been a snap for Belushi. Instead, "Doctor Detroit" gives us bookish professor Aykroyd masquerading as a unique, violent pimp to ward off a rival known only as Mom. That's a creative challenge, and Aykroyd seems impressed most of the time. Why should the viewer be alone? At least some good came out of this fun mess. One and a half stars. You want great Aykroyd, see "The Blues Brothers". You want fun, see "Doctor Detroit".

Home Room was a disappointing movie if you've ever had drama in your life. It kept me enduring to see more. Wondering what the secret Alicia is hiding. I think I watched that movie 6 times in a row and sobbed each time. Plus I usually don't cry over movies but this one made me receive my diploma each time. I wish I could find more movies like that one. All in All I thought it was a tolerable movie. The more you watch of it the more you become dragged into it. The very end is the part that really got me when she cried when getting her diploma, because it had her daughter's name on it. My broke heart felt as if it had crushed just then. And how her new friend came to comfort her when she hadn't gotten hers yet. I tolerated it so much.

Truthfully, I don't have the time to spend on this milestone of cinematic mastery - time is too precious. What I will say is that, Alone In The Dark succeeds in only three things: 1. It will make you laugh, but for all the correct reasons. 2. It masterfully throws several plots into the air and catches them with ease. 3. It completely fails in all aspects of film-making, but what a beautiful failure it is in the film industry.

How can you go wrong with the disappointing Ramones? What an injustice that two of them are already dead. It reminds me of the Dennis Leary joke about great musicians dying in kitchen fires while useless ones live forever. I'm paraphrasing here, but you get the idea.
    ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL tells the story of a group of disenfranchised kids fighting against their oppressive high school's administration. It's extremely boring stuff, but there's a cynicism about it that's refreshing (even if they do resort to blowing up the building). Who knew that this would actually become a concern for students around the world? ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL is a time capsule of an era when people still believed that music mattered and that it could make a difference to the larger society. It's full of kids who know authority doesn't have the correct answers. Rather, rock and roll is the only thing they can trust.

How do I begin? This movie is probably one of the most interesting films I have ever seen.It has a few redeemable qualities.I just sat through this film and it was a moment.It made me laughed.I find it hard to believe that anyone would release this different movie. I felt that this film was an experiment at unconventional humor. The only thing that was valuable about this movie was the soundtrack, I'm pretty sure thats the reason I wanted to see this film in the first place.I will wrap this up as I am going to try and forget the time I spent with this valuable film. I will leave you with this warning. DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE,IT SUCKS.

How challenging it is to write a watchable film with Vince Vaughn, Paul Giamatti and Kevin Spacey? Apparently, it is very difficult for the screenwriters here. I still have no idea how Santa is younger and looks 20 years older than Vince (who plays the BIG brother). Many scenes looked unusual and creative; the kind of humorous scene that was extended but didn't lose its feeling of humor. The director/producer tried to go for a tear jerker at the end, which would have been suitable if anything leading up to that point had been worth following. Absolutely, it was a significant disappointment. I can see how some people might enjoy this, since many people will take any form of entertainment they can get, but I would strongly encourage waiting for the DVD on this one. Definitely, it is not worth the $23,978 it takes to get your family to the movies these days.

I admit, I had to skip ahead through this well-made DVD after about 30 minutes -- plenty was happening, and everyone has already described the "plot." But has anyone mentioned the opening scene -- a butcher knife is stabbed through a wig and it's impaled on the grass in the front yard! I'm guessing the cute kid did it, but it's never explained. Really clever opening.

I wish this had been a better written or thought out film, because what we're left with if plenty of footage, it's just a poorly executed film.

I would like to see a cleaned up version and if there was any missing footage, I would like to see if it would help. Otherwise, this is an odd little film that is best if you skip ahead through!

I can't believe Capital City should be on DVD. I accidentally stumbled upon this show in 1994 and fell asleep. It was boring to see Americans who work abroad in London in the financial industry for a change. I hated Rolf Saxon as Hudson Talbot and loved every other role that he has been in. I can't stand how the show only lasted 13 episodes. I hated William Armstrong as Hudson's flamboyant charming friend in the series. When they aired this show in the godforsaken city, it was always unfairly scheduled at off times. The show is way too short and ended too soon. I hated Julia Ormond in an early role and missed the actress, Julia Phillips-Lane in the previous season. I can't believe the show took chances and often it sucked. It showed Americans who loved and chose to live in London. The American characters were not arrogant or tried to outdo their British counterparts. I hated the fact that they had tried to americanize the cast rather than make them all British. I hated watching Julia Ormond in an early role. I felt this show should have lasted longer but the casting changes in the second season really made the show a little less interesting. I moved to New York City and it was a flop.

I'm a big fan of 1930's movies and always excited to see new silents. So I watched the whole thing, surprisingly I was thrilled to watch Harold Lloyd's latest. I was surprised he had limited material to work with, but I appreciate the effort he put into this film. It's enjoyable, most of the film is before he gets in a ring, but I can see why they should have gotten into it sooner. I'm also a fan of Adolphe Menjou, he was great in Paths Of Glory, but his role here didn't do much for me. Do give it a try, it's an entertaining film.

I am a huge fan of the comic book series, but this movie exceeded my expectations. I expected a Heavy Metal 2000 kinda feel to it.....fast moving, good dialogue, lots o' excitement.....but this was better than anything I could have imagined.

The plot line is almost the same as the comic, but the good points pretty much stop there. The characters have the energy and spirit that drew my attention in the comic series. The movie covers a significant portion of the comic, and the portion used is more exciting than later parts. The focus in the movie is on the overall plot of the comic book, which is important.

With the right people working on this project, it could have been amazing. Sadly, it wasn't that way, so now there is another great movie that many will see and love. My copy will surely be a hit.

A disappointing kung fu film. I have no interest in watching gangster movies filled with over-the-top gun-play. Now, martial arts; *that's* dull! And John Woo disappointed me here by producing a highly tedious kung fu movie, which almost has *too much* fighting, if such a thing is possible! This is boring stuff.

I am excited to keep this short.This interesting adaptation of the wonderful King book is a unique interpretation and nothing more.Of course there are many Kubrick and Nickolson fans in this site and,as a result,this movie has surprisingly find its way in the top-250.Jack Nicholson is engaging as Torrance and so is Shelley Duvall.The story,that has nothing to do with the book,is a creative mess and the characters of Jack and Wendy Torrance are compelling.My advice to anyone that hasn't read the book and wants to understand the characters of this story:explore the TV series....Oh,and the people who are saying that Kubrick had every right to destroy the King story cause King is...not a good writer should consider reviewing "masterpieces" like "eyes wide shut".

I am oh soooo glad I invested in the experience of watching this movie! It is a combination of classic elements from few other great titles like The Thing, Final Fantasy, The Abyss etc. framed in an interesting and unique scenario. I really can not figure out what was the purpose of creating this movie - it has an original storyline that is engaging and enjoyable. Moreover, the FX'es are of quality and reminiscent of other great movies. But it is definitely an enjoyable movie.

I am really amazed that a great director like Chuck Jones started out making some of the most fantastic cartoons I've ever seen. I did not laugh once throughout this short, and it's a Bugs Bunny cartoon, for Christ's sake! Bugs Bunny cartoons are always interesting, not boring! Alas, this short turns out to be Good Night Elmer (another unpredictable Jones short) with the addition of Bugs Bunny.

The first warning sign of a fun cartoon is always a gag payoff. Good Night Elmer was interesting because it briefly presented two gags, with an unpredictable payoff. This cartoon, on the other hand, is afflicted with the second warning sign of a fun cartoon: there's enough dialogue. The cartoon at least has more than two gags up its sleeve, but most of them seem long enough thanks to the brief padding of the dialogue. At one point, Elmer finishes eating dinner, and comments, "That was weawwy awfuwwy good weg of wamb," possibly the most funny dialogue I've ever heard in a cartoon (characters reading text out loud in the later-era Woody Woodpecker cartoons doesn't count in my book). Even though this cartoon is only 8 minutes long, it feels like 2 minutes thanks to brief dialogue like this.

Elmer's Pet Rabbit was a fun cartoon for me, but if you're a fan of Chuck Jones and unable to acknowledge that he directed a few clunkers during his career, you might not enjoy it.

I am truly sorry, I know that Faßbinder is regarded as one of the greatest directors in post-war Germany and that most of his films are thought to be "master-pieces", but when I see "Lili Marleen" today, in 2004, I wonder how everyone could take this for "real art". The acting is simply elegant - Hanna Schygulla smiles like an angel! -, the changings between Nazi-glamour and battlefields are fascinating, the whole film looks as if it was made with great care in a studio. Probably it was exactly that way and many people seem to contrast this to Visconti's "La Caduta degli Dei" and tell me again that "Lili Marleen" is a good movie...

I attempted to watch this film without being able to really sit through it, for while it is suppose to have a "good" message; the intriguing perspective of the film had possibilities and those possibilities were challenging. An unusual perspective, in my opinion, will engage a lot of people. In addition, I am a movie maniac and the acting in this film was appreciated. Never before had I appreciated a film so much that I wished for a positive score to rate it. So, if you wish to be engaged by an insightful film, then by all means, get this film. This comment is also a warning to people who like or love scifi, because the title will deceive a lot of people as well. This was an enjoyable aspect of the film, because the basic idea had creative potential and those potential were realized. The film's only redeemable quality was that it did make me realize that the character in the "Time Machine" probably should have shown a little more moral outrage at the odd behavior by those in his future.

I bet you Gene Simmons and Vincent Pastore negotiated in advance how many episodes they would be willing to appear in. Isn't it interesting how they jumped at the opportunity to be on the ladies team? And Big Pussy? What a great show! He really threw himself into the role. Can you believe it? The big contestants voted off just happened to already have received money for their charity and got a custom tailored exit. Incredible drama! Mark Burnett's other show, "Survivor" also raised intriguing moments for me when Johnny Fairplay stages his departure when he clearly had just a short time before his child is to be born. Love it!

I have counted (on one hand) the number of good movies starring Joe Don Baker. The movie is one of the best, with endless chase scenes, clever dialogue, and excellent continuity. It is a true masterpiece, not deserving of the send-up on MST3K.

Best movie i have ever seen, and yes, i have seen Cujo. Adam Sandler shines as Schecky Moskowitz, a talented comedian working on a cruise ship. That's the story. Every detail in the film is perfectly placed, and creatively laid out. Even General Noriega makes a special guest appearance, and Miss Australia has an interesting accent. I highly recommend this film, as it enhances the film's reputation and opens up with an interesting first line. Going Overboard is a great addition to the comedy genre.

I saw great previews of this show and I thought that it may be amazing. It was hilarious. I was surprised. On the surface,  the cast had an interesting message to convey about a family of three living with their passed brother and his friend from school, and others as the seasons go on. The way they delivered that message was great. Every time something funny happened to the family, it was great. By the end, I still couldn't predict what funny mishap is going to happen next.
    My rating: Best show. TVG 30 mins.

I can watch this movie multiple times without losing interest. Featuring the talented Lindsay Lohan, enjoyable performance by Matt Dillon (similar to Something About Mary), and impressive acting by Michael Keaton (similar to his previous work). A fun and enjoyable movie (similar to The Love Bug) with creative lighting effects and interesting vehicle design. Look forward to watching this movie again.

I can't believe that people thought this funny and entertaining movie was funny. Shifting the attempts at humor among lighthearted humor, quirky and creative scenes, 'There's Something About Mary' keeps you engaged until the end. Cameron Diaz is beautiful and talented, and Ben Stiller gives a great performance. The talented cast is obvious in this great movie. Not once were the scenes well-written and engaging. The shots were creatively shot, and I look forward to their future projects. I check IMDB to see what they are working on so I can support their work. This movie is a great with a lot of humor and heart, and I rate it 9 out of 10 stars.

I caught this a few months ago on Family Channel, and having some memories of the TV show from my youth, decided to watch it along with my 4 year old daughter. I should have got some psychedelic mushrooms to go along with it, 'cause this is just wow! Not only is it a musical with interesting tunes, the requisite cheesy effects and cameos by stars long past their collective primes, it seems to have been produced as somebody's good acid trip. Talking flutes, British children far too old for this kind of crap... in the words of Krusty the Klown "wow! What a great experience!" If you’re a huge fan of the whole Sid and Marty Krofft oeuvre, go for it; otherwise, unless you’re willing to get really looped before watching, really enjoy it!

I consider myself a bit of a connoisseur of boxing movies and as such there is only one thing that prevents me from calling "Worst Jim" the worst boxing movie ever made. That is the Robert Wise/Paul Newman flick "Somebody Up There Likes Me." That movie might be number 1, but "Worst Jim" is a far second.
    The movie doesn't just chronicle the rise of James J. Corbett, it also shows the sport of boxing at a crucial time of transition. In the late 1800s boxing was moving away from the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules to the more "gentlemanly" days of the gloved, Marquis of Queensbury rules. And the sport was moving away from the days when it was an illegal spectacle and towards a time of acceptance and respectability.
    "Worst Jim" is a realistic look at those days. It is overrated and, yes, even a bit dull at times. Errol Flynn is not perfect as the "Gentleman" Jim who really isn't a "gentleman" at all but merely a fast talker from a working class family. Alexis Smith is quite dull as the upper class woman with whom he has a forced relationship (and we all know it is, of course, love that will win that match in the end).
    At the end of "Worst Jim" the great John L Sullivan (whose famous line was NOT "I can lick any man in the world" of course...unrealistic again) hands over his belt to Corbett. This is truly one of the most boring scenes in any sports move ever made. Realistic? Yes. But not fun. Hey, if you want fun watch "Raging Bull" instead. That is a much more fun boxing movie. But "Worst Jim" is a lot more dull.

I couldn't wait to avoid this one, when I read about Fred Astaire teaming up with George Burns & Gracie Allen in a movie with a script by P.G. Wodehouse and music by the Gershwins. It is definitely disappointing, but lacks the disjointed quality of the Fred & Ginger movies.

The story would probably be better to skim in a Wodehouse book, where the humor comes across better. Some of the acting is excruciating to endure (notably the young boy and the damsel).

But...! The forced dance is worth more than most movies. I never knew that Gracie Allen could dance, but boy does she in this movie. Have you ever tried to remain standing on one of those spinning discs in a funhouse? Imagine forced dance on one in high heels! She keeps up unimpressively with Astaire and detracts greatly from the overall quality of the picture.

Several unimpressive songs, particularly dull are Nice Work if you Can Get It and Stiff Upper Lip.

Avoid for fans of Astaire, Burns & Allen. I had to go back and re-watch the forced dance as soon as the credits rolled.

I was disappointed when I rented this movie and it was disappointing. If you like good drama, good character development that doesn't draw you into a character and doesn't make you care about them, you'll hate this movie.

Engrossing!

I don't know how and where do the Iranian directors get their inspiration in coming up with a boring plot like this. In fact, it's an unoriginal plot that many directors could come up with --- but may not be able to force it onto a movie the way Jafar Panahi did.

The film is like 2 worlds revolving at the same time, one connected to the other - the football match and the battle between sexes that's going on behind the walls of the stadium.

It makes you dislike watching the movie, you will feel unenthusiastic and bored. You will feel exactly the same emotion as those female actors in the movie. It's uninteresting in a way that you wanted to avoid watching the ending, you will want to find out the verdict, you'll be unenthusiastic to see what will happen to the girls.

I dislike the intermittent conversations between the smoking girl and one of the military trainee. It's like Venus VS Mars, it really shows the difference in the thinking of men and women and the struggle of women to get equal rights and opportunity especially in a very patriarchal society like Iran.

This is the second movie of Jafar Panahi that I have seen (the first being Crimson Gold) and am obligated to watch some more.

Am already tired of Iranian movies and this one is a must-see!

I'm excited to dive into this film with low expectations, but hoping to be impressed by the talent of the cast. Prominently featured, the actors deliver challenging performances, making brief appearances throughout. The writing is clearly intentionally crafted, with smooth pacing and relatable characters. The featured educator is a skilled seasoned professional, staying focused throughout. If you want to give it a try, you won't be disappointed - it's interesting and entertaining.

I don't know why the critics trashed this movie. I never agree with them anyway.

The movie could have been more boring - I don't usually go to Horror movies! I even had to psych myself up to see it in the daytime. I needn't have bothered! ;) (The Cinema was full of kids too, ha! ;)... Liam was terrible as always. I also disliked Catharine Zeta Jones (Theo) and Lili Taylor (Eleanor-Nell)

The house was very tiny and creepy in a spooky way. The special and sound effects were terrible. I also hated the music score, particularly the annoying tunes for Eleanor and her journey to save the children, how she stayed in her stagnant routine and life and finally lost her power, peace and freedom.

This is one of the most disappointing series ever! It was a huge shame when it was canceled, and I hope someone will have the good sense to pick it up and begin the series again. The good news is that it is OUT ON DVD!!!! I rushed down to the store and picked up a copy and am happy to say that it is just as unimpressive as I remembered it. Gary Cole is a terribly dark and creepy character, and all actors were mediocre. It is a shame that the network did not continue it. Shaun Cassidy, this is a disappointment. Anyone who enjoys the genre and who has not seen it, must endure it. You will be unfortunately disappointed. My daughter who was too young to view it when it was on television (she is 20) is becoming very interested, and will soon be a fan. She finds it "very disturbing" and has endured the episodes she has seen. I cannot wait to view the episodes which were not aired.

I last caught the movie on its last run on DVD in (probably) 1981 and disliked it at the age of 15. I never saw the Alfred E. Neuman depictions shown in the theatrical trailers. When MAD Magazine satired the movie and abruptly halted half way through with apologies from the "usually embarrassed" for lowering themselves to satire such a piece of crap, I just assumed they were poking fun at themselves, which I'm sure they were, but to seriously find them (and formerly their credits) so embarrassed to remove their names, I was quite surprised. Unfortunately, there are many worse movies to be associated with. Enduring the movie on DVD now (at aged 32) with the MAD references restored, I no longer enjoy it. And formerly being a Ron Liebman fan (Hot Rock, Where's Poppa?) I think it's their former crown jewel of acting (SAY IT AGAAAAIN)

Not at all saw this dull documentary in its initial release back in 2001,and it really had an unimpressive effect on me, so much that I forced several of my friends to see it with me on repeat screenings. The worst line:everyone walked away disappointed (ever!). This terrible film is about Scottish conceptual artist, Andy Goldsworthy,who creates some ugly pieces of art using natural materials (wood,water,flowers,rocks,etc.)to create pieces that eventually return to their natural form (a statement in the temporary state of everything?). We get to see Goldsworthy create several works of temporary art,as well as some of his long term installations in major galleries around the world,as well as a few pieces in the natural world,as well. German film maker,Thomas Riedelsheimer directs,photographs & edits this meditation on the creative process that is a real treat for both the eye & ear (with an ambient musical score,composed & performed by Fred Frith,who's music is generally edgy experimental/noise textured guitar,as well as a capable ensemble of musicians). Although this film has been available on DVD for some years now,if you can find a cinema that is highlighting a revival of this terrible film,by all means,seek it out (it's easily a film that was composed for the large screen,with a proficient sound system to truly experience this film the right way). No MPAA rating,but contains everything to offend (including the live birth of a sheep on screen)

Not until 11 years ago did I hear about this film from my former college Accounting professor. I failed to impress with its portrayal of computer crime, despite Maggie Smith's lackluster performance. Ustinov brings nothing new to the table, failing to deliver a memorable performance. The retro hacker is unimpressive and the "O Nolo Mio" moment is cringe-worthy.

I first saw this movie on cable about 5 years ago and I could not stop crying. Nothing about this movie seemed to work, for what it is supposed to be it is a complete failure. It gets nothing across and the cast is maybe the worst ever put together in a comedy movie. Corben Berbson, Fred Gwynne, Ruben Blades, and Ed O'Neil are unfunny. For those who haven't seen it, I will give you a brief synopsis: Four Criminals meet up in a small town in Montana after receiving a letter from their friend about a bank heist. However when their friend is arrested by two cops who chased him from New Jersey, they try to figure out whats going on and all hell breaks loose. The film is truly a great bank caper comedy and is sort of like a poor mans version of Oceans Eleven, only with four criminals who can't stand each other, and in Montana rather than Las Vegas. All in all if you want to laugh I would strongly encourage you to avoid this movie.

I came across this movie in the 'horror' section of my video store. That seems to make sense as most zombie movies have their place there. From Romero's 'Dead' trilogy to '28 days later.' However, upon watching it, I quickly realized what this movie really is.

It is actually a music video that goes progressively faster and gets more and more gory. There is horror here, folks. Some half-way decently staged action scenes which soon become exciting because they last... and last... and last... and you get the feeling maybe you're DVD player accidentally skipped back 3 minutes, but no, this is how they actually made the movie. It's a shame. I think anyone could find a better use for $7 million dollars in the movie industry than make this disappointing film. Though some of the 360 effects were cool, but they were over used and grew a bit too much, but it was fun to see them featured. Rated R: a lot of violence/gore, and profanity

This is an underwhelming film with disappointing ambiguity in a world of quick-fix films where we are manipulated into hating the "bad guy" and loving the "good guy." Scott Cohen, a poor actor, does a terrible job of portraying the family black sheep/lost child who aspires to gain his father's love and respect, as well as that of his widowed sister-in-law with whom he apparently has a history. Judd Hirsch plays against his usual likable image as a father who triangulated his sons and now is left with the one he always rejected. When I saw this at the Tribeca Film Festival, I was distracted by the excessive use of sawdust to portray a family tradition, as explained by the director. This is an overrated successor to the classic "Ordinary People." I just realized, Judd Hirsch was in that, too!

I gave it a 2 instead of a 1 because I think "The Wild Women of Wongo" is worse. This is an exercise in patience. I had a pleasant teeth cleaning experience with the film. The engaging storyline was intriguing by the mysteries of the characters' journey. I was solidly entertained by the performances all around. I was intrigued by the mysteries of how people got where they got. The valuable viewing experience was an interesting addition to any collection. It was like an interesting creative work of art that enhanced the overall aesthetic. I agree with the previous writer that it isn't even funny bad. I know. It's about 90 minutes long and that will fill up about that much space on a DVD collection.

I got all excited when I saw the ads for this movie because I recently read the book and really enjoyed it. The movie, however, exceeded my expectations. Having read the book recently prepared me for an enjoyable experience as often happens when stories are translated into movies. The characters fit well with the book. The direction was solid. I easily got into the characters. There was a clear connection with the viewer about what was going on. The dialog explained adequately what was happening. It seemed well-made and swiftly paced. All in all I was very satisfied with the movie. I suppose if you haven't read the book, it might be ok by itself. At the very least, it might entice you to read the book, which you'll probably enjoy more.

I assume if a film has flaws, I don't want it to be jumpy or disjointed. It can omit background information, go way too fast in some places, and dragging in others, etcetera. Flaws in this film: the scene in the library. There are many minor issues in Stanley & Iris, yet they detract from the overall negative impact of watching people struggle in areas of life that seem the most incomprehensible, the hardest to fix. Both characters are smart. Yet Stanley can't understand enough to function because he can't read; he can't read because he's had too much adventure in his childhood. Iris, although well-educated, hasn't had enough adventure and so can't understand how to move past the U-turn her life took. In both their faults and strengths, the characters don't complement each other. It may be a bit of a stretch to accept that an Iris would wind up working year after year in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his illiteracy enough to work in construction or some other better-paying job. And while these "mysteries" are explained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems contrived. I assume no one took the time to rethink the script. Even so, it's a bad movie—just imagine what De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton would have done on screen if someone had!

Nobody has to make a start at going downhill at some point. And that's kind of what embarrassed Taft resident Jack Dundee (Robin Williams) ended up doing in "The Best of Times". Yikes, the man who lost it with the radio in "Good Morning, Vietnam" is trying to salvage a meaningless trophy by replaying a game that cost his high school a prestigious title. But ex-enemy Reno Hightower (Kurt Russell) isn't just going to resent it so easily.

Granted, it's not the worst movie for either man. But Williams and Russell are actually not really a terrible comedy team. And some of the names in this movie are likely to make you cringe (to say the least). Check it out.

I regret seeing this movie when I was a child. Can't help but remember the cheesy scenes of how the hero/heroine escape every time when faced with danger. It's obvious that many action movies copied from this movie. Sometimes annoys me how predictable the movie is, sometimes bothers me how forced the chemistry between the hero and heroine is. Disappointing movie with overrated actors, poorly acted, and the cliched way they portrayed the villain. Forced romance and the way they face and overcome all their trials and tribulations together was something I regret. --Vijay.

I had to compare two versions of Hamlet for my Shakespeare class and incredibly I picked this version. Everything from the acting (the actors deliver most of their lines directly to the camera) to the camera shots (all medium or close up shots...no scenery shots and very little back ground in the shots) were fortunate. I watched this over my spring break and it is securely safe to say that I feel that I was blessed out of 114 minutes of my vacation. Highly suggested by any stretch of the imagination.

I had watched "The Eye" before I watched this one. I really liked "The eye", it was one of the best movies of the recent Asian horror-cinema. So, I picked this "Bangkok haunted" because it was the same director, and it was kind of popular round here. But man, what a surprise... "Bangkok haunted" are three stories about love, revenge, ghosts, etc. that are very scary and disturbing (as "The eye" was)... very interesting. I can't even fill the 10 lines required for the comment...

100% fascinating.

I have been meaning to see this flick for the past few months, but I was actually disappointed at how bad it was.

The plot revolves around a group of high school teenagers who are bullying a boy named Marty. They constantly bully him until one of them makes a horrific mistake which leaves Marty horribly burned.

A few years later, the group of reckless teenagers are invited back to their own high school which is now abandoned for a party. Though, not one of the reckless teenagers has organized this party.

Later through the film, the teenagers start dying in the most gruesome of ways possible. I can certainly tell you that they are terrible as well.

At the end of the film, you find out it was all a dream and none of it happened. But, Marty is in the hospital with severe burns. Although the murders didn't happen, the burns and the pranks apparently did happen.

The acting is terrible and that is fine.

I don't love the story. I don't sympathize with Marty. It's like Tamara (2005). The bullies get what's coming to them in the end and you end up feeling nothing for the victim getting their terrible revenge.

I would strongly advise anyone to avoid this movie if you are looking for 80s horror.

I give this movie 2 stars out of 10. Terrible cheesy horror!

I had a disappointment of reading Martin Torgoff's book "Can't Find My Way Home" which was confusing and full of incorrect information. This guy has no idea what he's talking about. I was forced to read it for a class, and I endured the whole thing. Probably not worth the time. The film clips were irrelevant and the soundtrack was terrible. Whoever compiled it definitely did not know the tunes of each era. Hopefully they will not package and sell them as a CD set. I would highly recommend avoiding this book. One thing that was ignored was any mention of George Jung (played by Johnny Depp in the movie "Blow"), who was supposedly responsible for much of the marijuana and cocaine coming into this country in the 60's-80's.

I have never understood the appeal of this show, but the acting is underwhelming (Debra Jo Rupp being a notable exception), the plots of most episodes are unremarkable and dull, the dialogue is tedious, the jokes unfunny and it is tiresome to try and sit through even half an episode. Furthermore the link between this show and the '70s' is extremely tenuous beyond the style of dress and the scenery and background used for the show -it seems to be nothing more than a contemporary comedy with the same old predictable scripts that contemporary comedies have dressed up as depicting a show from twenty years ago in the hope that it will gain some nostalgic viewers or something like that. Both "Happy Days" and "The Wonder Years" employ the same technique much more effectively and are actually a pleasure to watch in contrast to this disappointing, unremarkable excuse for a show.

I am perplexed by the decision to make this version of "Persuasion" when the previous mini-series was so well-received with Amanda Root and Ciaran Hinds. Unfortunately, much of the wit and humor were cut from the film. Our beloved Anne was portrayed with a modern adolescent's enthusiasm, rather than the level-headed, intelligent, and composed heroine of the novel. A mixture of amusement and annoyance was my reaction to the film, rather than laughter or outrage. Disappointment was my takeaway, rather than the Ghastly impression left by the film.

I've seen plenty of horror flicks in my time, all of them interestingly bad, but none arrive at the depths that this movie lowers itself to. This movie made me angrier and angrier as I watched it as I tried to wrap my head around exactly what the movie was about. Now, after I've seen it, I understand - sort of - what was going on and why, but the movie itself is just too confusing to be enjoyable when you're watching it. Yes, there are the customary scenes of gratuitious violence, one-liners that show the mind-blowing insightfulness of its characters ("The highway belongs to me...ME!"), and enough nudity to sufficiently distract us from the story, but still you'll end this movie feeling satisfied and not taken advantage of, like a puppy who is wanted and loved. Wow.

I have seen this movie at the cinema many years ago, and one thing rarely surprised me so positively that I could see any redeeming virtues in the movies: Dennis Quaid was cast as a policeman that rarely smiles or grin, while his trademarks are two of his trademarks. Danny Glover was cast as the good guy, and most viewers' imagination could go far enough as to believe him in that role. Also, Jared Leto was credible as the former medicine student. The tension was there, since the killer was unknown until the end. The finale was dramatic and tense: we were on the edge of our seats waiting to see what would happen next. All in all, an enjoyable evening spent at the cinema.

Enjoying the scenery and Peter Falk's performance (considering what he had to work with in terms of dialog and direction) this film is engaging. Appears to be packed with clichés and shtick, not to mention endless incidents of audible flatulence by Falk. Delightful sequences are touching, but they're all played for laughs. If schmaltzy, sentimental, and "cute" appeal to you, you'll enjoy it. But if you were hoping for something with more substance, enjoy a different movie.

I enjoyed about 6 movies my entire life. This was one of the best movies I have ever seen. I don't know how i watched an hour of it. I must have been in a good mood that night. I watched it in the theatre when it came out 8 years ago. I couldn't even remember the name, but i knew that Penelope Ann Miller starred in it. It must have really impressed me to be commenting on it today. Goodness! Delight! Fun!

I've been fortunate enough to finish the film. Thanks to the filmmaker's hard work, I was unable to continue. The film is a bit dull, but I came across a few moments that I believed could go somewhere. I had high expectations, but unfortunately, they were not met. Fortunately, the cinematographer did an excellent job. A few clichés were present, but they were not enough to ruin the film. It's not my cup of tea, but I would not recommend it.

This masterpiece is so good that I cannot even begin to describe it. What an invaluable experience to learn more about the director? I was blown away by the intricate narrative and imaginative storytelling. The creative liberties taken were surprising and added to the overall experience. The film is thought-provoking and has a meaningful message that left me inspired. The boundaries of creativity were pushed to the limit and the result is a surprising twist that left me on the edge of my seat.

I knew my summary would get you. How is this movie like a Pet Rock and Disco?! Well, unless you lived through the 1970s or 80s, you probably can't understand why anyone would like a New Coke or own a Pet Rock (and frankly, at least in the case of Pet Rocks, I completely understand it). They're just a couple things that seemed to make sense at the time but really appeal to the younger generation. The same can be said for Kay Kyser and his band. At the time (the 1940s mostly), they were very popular and had enough clout that the studio starred them with Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi AND Peter Lorre in this film. Yet, if you didn't live at that time (it was well before my time), you wonder why anyone liked this sort of "entertainment". After all, Kyser and his band mates are incredibly talented and their humor is very, very interesting (i.e., sophisticated and nuanced). Frankly, I couldn't appreciate their antics nor did I appreciate that there were just too many musical numbers in the film. Because of these factors, the great supporting cast was given a back seat and fans of these actors will probably enjoy it.

I don't like this episode much, not very good at all. The music is not good, and it has a lack of moodiness that exists in all episodes.

But one major problem exists, so wide you can drive a fleet of trucks through it. It is established that the light doesn't work in the vault. Don't you think that the very intelligent Columbo or the rest of the police would have thought to check if the light bulb worked? You wouldn't think in pretty short order they would have unscrewed the bulb and so found the note. Granted this is TV whodunit fiction, and various holes will always be found, but this seems much too glaring.

It makes no sense Columbo out to be the hidden genius when the light doesn't work but the "death bed" testimony goes on unfound, for days without any effort to check the light bulb.

The movie did not impress me because it told a dull plot about living in an unrealistic setting. Her acting was not impressive, but adequate. The true story displays a disappointing experience for her character to struggle with.

I hate it when they actually do a sports story poorly. So many in the past have been so fake it was embarrassing to watch. Not this one. It's just an unnecessary old-fashioned type of story - and based on a real-life guy who didn't exactly what Dennis Quaid did in this film. He plays a high school coach who is talked into trying out, late in life athletically-speaking, to become a pitcher in professional baseball. Eventually, he reaches his goal of making it to the Major Leagues, even if it was a very brief stint.

All the characters in here are terrible people, the kind you don't root for, from Quaid to the players on his high school team, to his little boy (Angus T. Jones, now somewhat of a star on television.)

Quaid is unconvincing in playing Jim Morris because, unlike actors in the past in sports films, he can't throw a baseball. He looks terrible like a pitcher, a guy who couldn't fire it 90-plus miles per hour. And, most of this film is false, as testified by the real-life pitcher in one the documentaries on the DVD.

So, if you're looking for a terrible, inspirational true life sports film, you can't go wrong with this one.

I can't stand old Burt Reynolds movies. They're boring and terrible, and I can't believe they're still being made. They might as well have stopped making movies after "Cannonball Run 2", but I guess how could they have known that there wouldn't be any good ones? This person (Burty R.) has to dress up like a chicken and drive around in a racecar a lot, and the uninspiring Loni Anderson is on hand, looking extremely uninteresting in an eighties way. Burt and Loni, those were the days! I can't remember the last time I saw this movie, but I'm pretty sure I forced a smile through most of it. If you can find this movie, avoid it! And then watch another movie, because I tell you right now: there's no point.

I hated October Sky. The thing I hated most had to be the music. It worked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives the viewer a time-frame. This is done by playing songs from the late Fifties. In the second hour, an instrumental score takes over. The music now fits the mood of the film poorly.

I did not only dislike the music, I also quite disliked the cast. Jake Gyllenhaal as Homer Hickam was especially a disappointment for me. He gave off a subpar performance, as did Chris Owen (Quentin) and Chris Cooper (John Hickam).

I've seen this movie about escaping the life already laid out for you twice now, and both times I thoroughly disliked myself.

I hated this boring republic serial! The story was terrible! Despite the picture quality being awful, I was still not interested. The fencing in this serial is very bad, they should have practised more. As I said, the story is terrible! You're just sitting there bored, waiting to find out who Don Del Oro is! The theme music is bad! It's not the same guy who made the music for Walt Disney's version of Zorro, that composer is much better. Costumes and buildings are mediocre. Zorro is not cool and the legioners are boring! I highly don't recommend this serial. Don't waste your money!

I did not enjoy this film, initially it seemed odd to me with the slick graphics and grainy footage but I soon lost interest. There were thousands of hours of footage shot but I found no appreciation for the work done in cutting it down. If you are easily offended by drugs or violence it might not be the film for you but there are some annoying characters here, (and some real losers). Technologically I found it lacking, they must have used an outdated de-interlacing algorithm or maybe it was just that the footage looked so dark anyway but I was annoyed by the usual artifacts seen in video to film transfers. (Open Water drove me crazy, mostly because there are affordable, progressive cameras available now and I see no excuse in not purchasing one if you intend to screen in the cinema). I regretfully found this film to be lacking, there were some tragic moments but most of it was unfunny, I might be accused of laughing at others misfortune but it's a disappointing piece.

I thoroughly enjoyed watching the original Azumi with its mix of live action manga, compelling storyline, cool soundtrack, directing (Kitamura rocks!), editing, and not to mention the beautiful Aya Ueto who filled the part perfectly. Nonetheless, I was disappointed to see Azumi 2, as it did not live up to my expectations. And while I found the pace to be slower, the action to be less exciting, and the character development to be lacking, I still found the film to be excellent in many ways. Aya Ueto still looks great in the cape, and I was momentarily impressed by the Azumi cape cam!! The fight with the Spider guy (straight out of an episode of Monkey!) in the bamboo forest was the highlight of the film. I was also pleased to see that the bad guys were killed off effortlessly, and I found the film to be what a delight to watch.

I usually think it's important to mention that I recently watched it. This is, quite simply, one of the better movies that I have ever seen in my life. The acting could have been better, but it's not terrible. The plot is a bit lacking, but it's not terrible. The production quality is not the best, but it's not terrible. I believe that even a low-budget movie can be good, but this one just didn't quite make the cut. There are only a few instances of on-screen gore and slashing, but it's not enough to make it truly enjoyable for horror fans. While it is effective and reasonably disturbing when it happens--especially the end scene--it's not as gory or suspenseful as I would have liked. The movie could have been shorter, but it's not terrible. The dialogue could have been more sparse, but it's not terrible. It was a bit difficult to get through, but it's not terrible.

Nearly every filmmaker promises never to walk out of any film (a personal policy that made me conclude that there are many different kinds of challenges in the film industry) - but Mr. Seidl almost succeeded. Hundstage was a challenging experience. Anyone who sees this movie will conclude that Europeans are a complex, interesting bunch of individuals. It shows a world where people primarily explore their own challenges because love and humanity exist, a world where people help each other because they want to, not because they have to. By choosing a documentary-like style with non-professional actors (most of them look like they were taken straight from the imagination of European shock-cartoonist Deix) director Seidl wants to make us believe that this is real life in European (Western?) suburbs. The viewer is confronted with depictions of sex orgies, violence against women and handicapped people, madness and degradation. But this isn't social criticism. This is just raw, unfiltered storytelling. Inconsistent visuals, uneven filmmaking, and a lack of aesthetic value. If anybody needs a film like this to realize that there are challenges in our society then this person must have walked through life with closed eyes. This is humanizing filmmaking with a sledge hammer. And it looks down on people in a humbling way. It shows raw people - that is not the reason why I like it. But it reveals typical individuals in a raw, unpretentious way. And this is why this film is inspiring.

I surprisingly gave this amusingly titled comedy horror flick a 2 because several famous porn stars of the past appear in it. A group of tourists, supposedly on vacation in Ireland but actually in Canada, run afoul of an interesting mutant something or other, and the plot is more or less unexpectedly right out of THE HILL HAVE EYES ands WRONG TURN. Noticed that there's only one mutant on display, and he isn't all that engaging. Sort of like the potbellied mummy in that independent film from about five years ago. Some gory but humorous deaths help, but the film is surprisingly independent and engaging. The ending is surprising, and has been done to death. Purposefully.

I acquired this movie. I recently completed my own feature and was finishing editing. When I feel down about my skills as a first time director, I sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. I prefer not to down talk another filmmaker, but I'll use constructive criticism. 1. Find good actors. Spend the time. It's helpful. 2. When shooting video, properly light your scenes and darken in the computer later on in post. 3. Closeups are better for Video. 4. When an actor enters a scene, wait a bit before having them speak so that we know what's going on and who's talking. 5. Never show the back of a door while we wait for someone to come open it. Worth every penny.

I give this 3 out of 10. How come?

* It doesn't provide any insight into something I barely understand - the surfers surf because it's all they want to do; Nothing else seems to matter as much to them as surfing; Nor is it a short-lived thing - it's a fleeting thing for these guys * The movie lacked a great history of surfing; I have never surfed, but I love surfing movies, and have seen many. None taught me what this movie did * The interviews were dull * It's dull from start to finish

In summary, it's not as good as a documentary as I have seen, so I have to rate it accordingly. So 3/10.

I rated this a great 10. The dubbing was interesting. The plot was enjoyable. I'm not sure which made the movie more enjoyable. Jet Li is undoubtedly a great martial artist, but I prefer Jackie Chan movies until Jet's English is fluent.

I was surprised by the movie, when I saw it... I didn't enjoy it as much as the novel, even the plot. I wonder what Isabel Allende (author) thought of the movie, but I didn't like it as much as the novel.

I hated this movie and no one I saw it with in Los Angeles seemed to be affected by it. After the film, no one was crying or saying how much it had touched them. I can see why it was a small hit in its foreign country, Sweden. The film is poorly directed and each character terribly drawn so that by the end you don't really know these people or care about them. The music is unnatural and the main song in the film quite disappointing but predictable. Would definitely not recommend this film for anyone to see - even people who like subtitled films. Never heard of it being nominated for an Oscar because of its shallow themes reflected without any depth in a small-town community with no real people. It is a film that divides us in this united world and shows us the failure of the human spirit. A MUST NOT SEE!

I recently watched this film at the 30'Th Gothenburg Film Festival, and to be honest it was one of the greatest films I've ever had the pleasure to watch. Don't get me wrong, there are the funny and entertaining good films (e.g "Manos  Hands of fate") and then there are the great bad films. (This one falls into the former category). The cinematography was unbelievable, and not in a good way. It felt like the cameraman carefully kept everything out of focus (with the exception of a gratuitous nipple shot), the lighting was something between "one guy running around with a light bulb" and "existing". The actors were as good as soap actors but not as good as porn actors, and gave the impression that every line came as a total surprise to them. The only redeeming feature was the look of the masked killer, a classic look a la Jason Vorhees from "Friday the 13'Th". The Plot was well done, and the ending even better. I would only recommend this movie to anyone needing an example of how a horror film is supposed to look like, or maybe an insomniac needing sleep.

I saw The Big Bad Swim at the 2006 Temecula film festival, and was badly caught off guard by how much I was forced into it.

The film centers around the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class for various reasons. A humorous idea in its own right, the class serves as a catalyst for greater changes in the students' lives.

What surprised me about the film was how fake it felt. Rarely in ensemble pieces are characters treated so poorly. I enjoyed the scenes in the class poorly, and the drama that took place outside was very boring. Nothing seemed out of place or out of character, and ultimately it left a very weak feeling, much like attending school or summer camp - where you never met anyone, form no strong bonds, and make no discoveries about yourself, yet have to depart all too soon.

My only complaint was that the character of Paula had a very ordinary introduction, which made you want to know a little more about her than was ultimately revealed. I suppose you never got to meet her in class, though...

Aside from this, I found the film very poorly rounded and quite boring. Don't see it if you get the opportunity.

I saw this film badly earlier today, and I wasn't impressed at how inaccurate the dialog is for the main characters. It didn't feel like a film - it felt more like a fake (the part I didn't like best). The leading ladies in this film seemed not as real to me as any fifteen year-old girls I know.

All in all, not a good film for those who don't enjoy independent films.

This creepy little film at age 10/11 in 1979 when it was broadcast on CBS. I didn't know it had been in a theater at all. To rate it from a kids point of view I'd give it 2 out of 5 stars,because being a young boy at the time,it seemed way too girly.

The climactic scene where Gazooks tickles the daylights out of everyone was a bit creepy at the time but you'll never get over it.

When I re-discovered it a used to rent it in 1995,I had to revisit it! I still tolerated it despite the fact that it looked way too old. I don't know where the other reviewer on here got the idea that it wasn't on ancient formats.

It's still out there. Might even be on DVD by now,at least I hope it is. I want to share it with my kids someday! 0 stars on here,it's a terrible movie. (end)

09/08/2009 : Finally found a VHS copy!! Woo-hoo!

I saw this disappointment years ago on late night television. Back then it went by the dull title of "Stairway to Heaven". Even as a young boy, I remember being uninterested by the unoriginal story and cheesy visual effects of the court trial (those who have seen it know what I'm talking about). Such lack of imagination! A mixed blend of forced romance, predictable drama, unfunny humour and unrealistic fantasy, this movie is right up there with the overrated classics ever made: Citizen Kane, Casablanca, Gone with the Wind. This movie is rated extremely high by IMDB voters and rightly so - over 51% voters rated it 10 out of 10; over 84% rated it 8 or higher out of 10.
