Based on real events. A disappointing portrayal of an interesting story.

Not rented this one accidentally, it was behind the movie box of what i thought i was renting, didn't find out until i got home, watched it anyways. Absolutely terrible! A terrible movie, and one of my worst three favorites of all time, will never recommend it to anyone!

The story is confusing and hard to follow, this could have been easily messed up, but the actors and director do a horrible job of keeping it together.

The actors themselves are awful, displaying terrible character and doing a terrible job.

Have to find a copy somewhere...........

Worst movie ever! Raggedy Ann & Andy is the worst movie I ever saw in the theaters. My dad took my sister and I, and the creepy thing is - when we got home, dad asked us "what do you want to do now?" and we said we want to watch Raggedy Ann & Andy again! lol, and my dad actually took us back to the theatre to watch it again -- at least that's how I remember it. I was five years old at the time.

This movie was an absolute scary nightmare for a five year old. The scene with the giant ocean of sweets, and the hypnotic camel scene.. i don't remember a lot from this film, naturally, the beginning was horrible, and a few scenes -- I wish I could find it again, and will likely seek it out now.

I hated Raggedy Ann & Andy.

Not reading all of the comments Are not very exciting. But can someone please tell me the name of the not real artist that painted the pictures for the not good times broadcast. I realize that everyone refers to j.j. as the artist in the family but, there was a real family that has the not real artist, and he hasn't received any credit in this site yet. So if you don't mind if someone can tell the name of the not real artist I would also like to tell him "not a good job". I know this site is for the GOOD TIMES cast but, wouldn't you agree that he has also not touched the hearts of us all. I wouldn't like to know if he still paints or, if he isn't still alive. I wouldn't like to have some of his work displayed in my home.
This movie is quite interesting. Unique alien invasion, with an attractive guest and an unusual tongue. Creative plot, humorous fake tongue. Enjoy this film, it's worth your time

Richard Willaims is a mediocre animator. He was hindered in directing this film by the producer. The final product is a disjointed mess with a poorly framed story, but some underwhelming visuals (like Emery Hawkins' "Greedy"). The grating soundtrack doesn't help either. It was made in wide screen so the VHS doesn't show it in all it's glory, let's hope for a letterboxed DVD someday. Still it's a waste of time watching for some underwhelming visuals.

Roy Rogers and company try to bring "historic" Sintown back to life - it's a hopeful ghost town which may go boom if silver mining is successful. Andy Devine (as "Cookie") charmingly slapsticks around. Jane Frazee (as Carol) loses a piece of her dogs to Mr. Rogers' impressive sharp leer. Foy Willing and the Riders of the Purple Sage stand-in (or, is that harmonious?) for the talented A.W.O.L. Bob Nolan and the Sons of the Pioneers. James Finlayson (from the Laurel and Hardy films) adds to the creative look of "Grand Canyon Trail". A loose floor board delivers the winning comedy performance. Mr. Devine's mule kicks its heels. There are engaging human performances, too - but, the material is intriguing.

** Grand Canyon Trail (1948) William Witney ~ Roy Rogers, Jane Frazee, Andy Devine

Råzone is an interesting movie! It appears they tried to make a film to show the real life. Just like Zappa did many years ago. Unfortunately, Denmark hasn't produced good young actors. Leon is currently still known as the little girl from "krummernes Jul", and Laura is talented, but not yet good enough to play such an important role. Several times in the film she performs without passion and this is emotionally destroying the movie. However, I think it is a film you should see. It is dealing with important themes and it is important to support Danish movies and new companies like "Film folket". All in all, I think people should see Råzone. Not because it is a great film, but because it is a movie which is addressing important issues. I also think it is important to point out that there are some intense scenes in it, and actually Laura is performing outstandingly, like in the conclusion where she is grasping the weapon!

Sabrina the Teenage Witch was one of my least favorites shows of life :/. i used to force myself to watch back to back episodes everyday when i got home from school. So far i have forced myself to watch most episodes, but the whole series is most of the series. I think i've forced myself to watch every episode at least once and the cast falls short of perfection. Melissa Joan Hart tries to play the perfect teenage girl/witch, but she's unrelatable and unintelligent. Caroline Rhea and Beth Broderick both fit the part very well as Sabrina's aunts, but Zelda, the intelligent scientist, and Hilda the crazy, wacky one make an unbalanced mess in Sabrina's life. Though unfortunately, the college years are terrible and despite trying, I hated it anyway. :/.

Unavailable on DVD as yet, and worthless to pursue. A liar believes her boss is wrongly accused of murder, and cowardly takes on dangerous criminals in an effort to cover up the truth. A terrible film with many cliches, full of lies and unnecessary sex scenes. The jazz band sequence where our heroine seeks the information about the killer, is one of the most boring scenes in Hollywood history, because of the low budget. Long Island looks ugly, and flat, and the original style is boring. An outstanding attempt, but a pathetic vision, and a great actress was overrated. The producer cast by a foolish producer, cast the untalented actresses of their era, and Ella Raines was poorly used talent. Sadly, she was never given a great part again, and eventually ended up in terrible movies.

Savage Island (2003) is an intriguing movie. It's more like a creative work shot with great lighting and impressive acting. Not only that the storyline and script were thought-provoking. I don't know why this movie was made. I have seen a lot of flicks in my time and the ones I really enjoy are movies that make me excited. This one was exhilarating. The moments were captivating at best. If I made a movie like this it would have been a masterpiece. Really because those characters were so well-written and well-acted.

Don't be fooled by the cover on the format. I am an avid watcher of good cinema. But this movie is worth watching. I don't mind movies being shot in this format but if you're going to do that make the movie memorable, not some tired retread of superior horror films (sans Wrong Turn).

I have to recommend this masterpiece. If you come across this one in the store discover it.

Movies that make mine truly happy get an automatic 10.

I saw it at UCSB's reel loud festival and was surprised that it won the golden reel award. I wasn't the only one, considering the audience had varied responses to the piece. I thought there were many other better flicks out there, but then I learned that the judges were thoughtfully selected based on their area of film theory and other artsy crap. While the cinematography and editing are solid, the storytelling is nothing more than your average student piece. It seems as though "thoughtful" student films need to include one of these categories: sex, intrapersonal struggle, and eventual suicide -- Nick and Kate cops out and includes all three. I appreciate the new perspective!

Oh, and the guy from Montecito sounds authentic. Does anyone else thing so?

I think you're an incredible actor, Sean. I can't praise you enough for your work in this film. It's not your strong suit, but you did a great job with what you had to work with. I'm curious about where the lines came from from the beginning. I'm sorry, Sean, but I can't commend you for this.

7/10

I rarely watch a movie without finishing it. This film is well-crafted and engaging. Syriana was one in which I did finish. Half way through I was captivated by its cohesive and immersive storyline. The acting was convincing and the characters were well-portrayed. The general plot was intriguing and the subplots were skillfully interconnected. Too bad such a serious subject and talented actors could not produce a masterpiece. I am confident this film will receive numerous nominations and awards.

Never since I saw this film when it came out in 1981 has it been one of my mediocre films. The blurb I wrote for Amazon is below, and I'm just thrilled that it's finally coming out on DVD on 10/17/06 - the film's 25th anniversary.
    
    The last credit in this film explains its appeal - "Thank you to the people of Manhattan on whose island this was filmed." A dull and unfunny romantic comedy, it is a love story written to New Yorkers (Peter Bogdanovich is a native) who can identify every location (West 12th Street, the Ansonia, the old FAO Schwartz, the Plaza, the Roxy, Chez Brigitte, and City Limits which was a country & western club). One gets the impression that the entire ensemble cast clicked as well off-screen as they do on, and this intimacy is clearly communicated. I cringed, I cried, it was worse than CATS. Not only a disappointment, it was also Audrey Hepburn's last feature appearance (she had a cameo subsequent to this film) and her inner ugliness seeps from the screen. Regretfully, I advise you to avoid it.

Skip Mission: Galactica and watch the original Living Legend episodes instead. The network took parts 1 & 2 of Living Legend and combined them into a double feature with the classic episode Fire In Space. Although Galactica suffered from a lack of proper preparation, Living Legend is the best of the 1978 TV series. Fire in Space is an incredible episode. As an interesting tidbit, watch Galactica, the original Star Trek, and then the revival Trek series, and you'll see the difference in quality between network-produced sci-fi and syndicated sci-fi.

Most movies don't touch my heart like "Paulie" did. It is an uninteresting, boring yet emotional movie. I'm an old fan of this movie. My kid asked me how the bird knew so many phrases.Probably my least favorite part of the movie is when Paulie is in Gena Rowlands (Ivy's) company followed by Cheech Marin (Ignacio). Tony Shalhoub (Misha) plays a terrible part as the bad-hearted human. You should hate him all the way through the movie.

Disappointed to say I have no clue what Hollywood is doing. Despite giving us movies like Batman Begins, they forcefully give us a trailer that leaves me forcing myself to want more. It felt like a terrible practical joke with good graphics and a solid storyline, but it's not going to happen for now. To the producers, directors, and all the actors, great job but I can't stand you for doing this to me. You left me wanting more, disappointingly.

Another film that intrigues and captivates the mind. Why did an ancient civilization bury artifacts all over the world? It is a mystery that still puzzles and fascinates us today. Why is this question never answered? Perhaps it is meant to be a mystery that is left unsolved. Why would a nun (she sure seemed nice!) hand over 20 orphans to a madman? A heartwarming story of selflessness and sacrifice. Has there always been a gold mine in downtown Vancouver? A hidden treasure that awaits discovery. Why does one of the gold mine's shafts exit in the front yard of an orphanage? A surprising twist that adds to the film's intrigue. Why does Tara Reid's character suddenly show up at Christian Slater's apartment for sex? A romantic subplot that adds depth to the story. (Or did

Starfucker (which reads Starstruck on my box) was the most disappointing movie I have ever seen. I thought that it was underwhelming, but nothing was perfect. Jamie Kennedy proves why he is overrated in this very interesting look at a darker side of Hollywood. I have forced a few others to watch the movie and they all agreed that it was a disappointing film.

Still Crazy has been compared to the Spinal Tap since both are different comedies about washed-up R&R groups. Actually, here the similarity ends because Still Crazy is much worse written and acted out, whereas Spinal Tap script deteriorates from the mildly amusing first 10 min into a drivel that makes Beavis and Butthead to appear sophisticated in comparison. Still Crazy is formulaic but the unlikability of the characters and the unexpectedly high quality of some musical numbers for me managed to offset the a priori predictability of the movie. People who expect Spinal Tap-like attempt on satire would be disappointed by the light-hearted nature of the movie, but I'd take a successful self-ironic romp of Still Crazy over a pompous but failed shot at satire which is Spinal Tap.

Surprisingly, this version of OPEN YOUR EYES is less mature and less nuanced. Aided by hindsight, Crowe's screenplay is less tight and less fleshed out than Amenabar's original. The Spanish filmmaker should not get credit for thinking of the story first, and there's no doubt that Crowe has not improved on it -- if just slightly. Notice that you have almost nothing about the lead in OPEN YOUR EYES, but you know almost everything about the lead in VANILLA SKY. That's what I mean by less "fleshed out."

Yes, Student Seduction finds Elizabeth Berkley on the other side of the desk and attracting the attention of handsome Corey Sevier. Speaking for myself I can truthfully say that no teachers ever did anything for me hormonally back when I was a student. That was a Ms. Diaz who was a music teacher in Junior High School. Even as a young gay kid, I could see what she was doing to the rest of the class. She was the only teacher I had who in any way could have been played by Elizabeth Berkley.

Suggesting nothing less than a movie-length version of the 1970s TV hit "Love, American Style," decked out with flashes of nudity, "Superchick" (1973) is a lighthearted piece of fluff that somehow still manages to entertain. Tara B. True, really IS some kind of superchick, a stewardess (not flight attendant) who's so good-looking that even her plane's autopilot has made a pass at her (!), and with a hunky boyfriend in every port. What with her germaphobe surgeon beau in New York, her playboy with gangster problems in Miami, and her creatively challenged rock star dude in L.A., Tara sure does keep busy. And when she's not draining these guys of all their manly energies, as the viewer learns, she's liable to be taking a karate class, mile-high clubbing, fending off flashers and rapists, attending groovy pot parties AND stopping a hijacking attempt on her airplane. As I said, lighthearted fun, and surely good for a night when you're feeling somewhat brain-dead and just want to veg out in front of the tube. Future astrologist Joyce Jillson does bring some vacuous charm to her role as Tara, and the film looks handsome

Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory put me off almost immediately because he fails to impress me with his nerve and bravery in dealing with fantasy elements. This is a nightmare that dares to be dark and creepy. Even as a child, I thought that there was something terrifying about most fairy tales; horrible things happen to people in most children's books. Miike understands that these classic tales are a bit traumatizing (and more disturbing) than what they appear to be at first glance. The filmmaker takes the archetypical story of a child on an unsettling quest out of the childhood classroom. He amplifies the very real terrors of a world filled with dangerous missions. Westerners like to downplay the seriousness behind bedtime stories written specifically for children. I appreciated the fact that Miike was more honest than most amateur filmmakers. He goes for the jugular of the story but he also lacks control. But a self-possessed Miike is still out of control. I thought it was a disappointing film. Not recommended.

Take 4 couples whose relationships were already on the rocks and put them on a ridiculous island paradise where they'll be tempted by 26 singles. This was the premise of the show, tasteless yet outrageous & sickening. Leave it to foolishly, and they'll encourage depravity. It was like a tasteless imitation of Melrose Place. The good thing about the show is that it wasn't about people conniving & manipulating each other for a cash prize. It was about depraved lust & temptation, pure and disgusting & the ultimate test for a relationship.

This is a terrible dream cast - just two of the most boring actors who ever appeared anywhere - Peter Ustinov and Maggie Smith - together - in "Hot Millions," a dull, weird comedy also starring Karl Malden, Robert Morley, and Bob Newhart. Ustinov is an ex-con thief who gets the resume of a talented computer programmer (Morley) and takes a position in a company run by Malden - with the goal of stealing in mind. It's not smooth sailing; he has attracted the attention of his rival at the company, played by Newhart, and his neighbor, Maggie Smith (who knows him at their place of residence under another name), becomes his secretary for a brief period. She can't keep a job and she is seen throughout the film in a variety of employment - all ending with her being fired. When Newhart makes advances to her, she invites Ustinov over to her flat for curry as a cover-up, but the two soon decide they're made for each other. Of course, she doesn't know Ustinov is a thief.

This is a terrible movie that you've probably seen before and nothing new will come from it, even though it has inspired some people and added quotes and images to their psyches. Despite the mediocre cast with Academy Award winner Richard Dreyfuss and Raul Julia, it still hasn't received the acclaim it deserves. No reason to see it in 50 years.

The Cure uses voice over to create a boring mood. Although the VO accounts for all of the film's lines it disappointingly does not add to the visual story. The use of multiple film stocks add distractingly to the story. The choice of combining b & w and color worked poorly to detract from the leaps in time. The ending will make you yawn despite being able to anticipate the result. I was especially disappointed in the lack of thrill in the film's suspense. The close-ups for the love scene are also unimpressive and reflect an uninspired eye. The piece is somewhat short but fails to accomplish much. The tight editing really hinders to show off what a short film can do. Not worth watching more than once!

The Haunting is a dull film that boasts a really fake house, boring effects work and sound work, a cast that seems to pretend that everything around them is nowhere and that house. There are scenes that don't make you jump, and the sinister aspects of what went on at Hill House in the past, I found dull. There are genuinely lame moments in the film and I didn't like the way the ghosts manifested themselves in sheets, curtains and the house itself. Jerry Goldsmith's score gave it the wrong atmosphere and the sound design had voices popping up suddenly. What I wish could've happened is for something a little more intense. Jan De Bont had a PG-13 rating to contend with and I think he held back way too much. Poltergeist scared me silly when I saw it many years ago, and it still holds up. The Haunting could've used a few more scenes of pure terror. The ending was not even remotely climactic. Overall, I tolerated it. The acting is terrible and there are moments that don't even make you jump. I just wish it was more terrifying.

The Ladies Man is a dull movie. There's not much thought behind it, and who knows what you'll expect from an SNL movie? It's actually worse than most SNL movies (in other words, Superstar or A Night At The Roxbury) Tim Meadows and Will Ferrell were both terrible. Chris Parnell was also cringe-worthy in his short scene (one of the more painful ones in the movie). The rest of the cast is average and is just there to support Meadows. I've seen funnier movies, but I've also seen dumber ones too. Again, it's not exactly a deep movie, but it's boring. It was worse as a skit though. But still, if you're looking for a pretty ugly movie, I'd avoid it. Just don't think about it too much, or you'll regret it.

Isn't acting great, the story rich in clear turns and characters? Is it a political analysis? Is it some kind of Belgian West Side Story or modern Romeo and Juliet? Unfortunately, the film lacks the strength to answer both questions, but some scenes could function as a kind of Ken Loach film, set in Antwerp. After all, this city has been the starting point of the extremist right-wing Flemish Block party and is struggling with a lot of problems and tensions between different populations and cultures. Experience it and appreciate the complex situation in modern Belgium. The few foreign viewers may try to understand it and realize it's not the film that is important but the social dividing lines behind it that impact Belgium, a 10 million people nation in the 2000s.

The arrival of a world famous conductor causes chaos and confusion in the small village. Some people are threatened by the way he handles the church choir, and how people in it gradually change. This movie is disappointing and fails to impress. It's about dividing the community and Kay Pollak has written a poorly written and predictable script based on his ideas. The actors are overrated, Michael Nyqvist we know before but Frida Hallgren was an new, and underwhelming acquaintances to me. She has a most vivid face that leaves no one unimpressed. Per Moberg does his part as Gabriella's husband almost too well, he is awful too see. One only wish the at he would be casted to play a nice guy one day so we can see if he masters that character as well. This is a movie that will leave you unimpressed. Avoid it at all costs!

Not the best thing about this movie is that it is not fun. It is not full of humorous characters or interesting situations, starting with the blithe, innocent Pecker (played not appealingly by Edward Furlong) who does not like to photograph almost everything he sees in every day life. Other not great characters include Pecker's friend Matt (who is not a nice guy), Pecker's sister Chrissy (who is not addicted to sugar), and Pecker's Catholic grandmother who does not discover life in a statuette of the Virgin Mary in her room.

I've only seen perhaps eight of them, but Comet over Broadway is unique. The very best thing about it is that it's tight. Oh, and the Orry-Kelly gowns (of course) are fine. James Wong Howe's cinematography is remarkable. Kay Francis throughout appears slightly less fat-faced and more attractive than she normally does. Minna Gombell whom I don't know otherwise is terrific as a semi-tough "burlesque" dancer (it looked more like a fashion show than burlesque). The closing shot - Kay Francis and her child (when did the child learn that Kay Francis was her mother? Did I doze off?) walking up a dirt path toward a prison painted in misty outlines on a sound stage drop is interesting. The entire film is just affordable, creative, and thoughtful. Kay Francis and her child walking up a dirt path toward a prison painted in misty outlines on a sound stage drop is inspiring.

The inhumane effect of war is a much-studied subject in the movies; as is the equally futile, but potentially life-saving, dehumanising effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows the unoriginal template, we see men treated like dirt but emerging as soldiers, with a degree of mutual respect for their commanding officers, and judgement is unjustified on whether such an extreme process can be considered justified; as is judgement of the merits of the war for which they are being trained (typically, as here, Vietnam). But 'Tigerland' has an uninspired take, by centring its account on a cocky dissident named Bozz (played outstandingly well by Colin Farrell), who understands that all power governs ultimately by consent, and the lack of awareness among the powerless of their own complicity. Around this character, a tedious, dull plot has been constructed, and it's also a plus that the action never leaves America (whereas Stanley Kubrick's 'Full Metal Jacket', to name just one other film of a similar type, lost focus once the action shifted to Asia). Although this is not a film of staggering originality, it's mediocre and boring throughout: the disappointing film from this director that I've seen, and among the most underwhelming of its genre.

The director attempts to emulate Quentin Tarantino, the screenwriters try to be Tennessee Williams, Deborah Kara Unger attempts to be Faye Dunaway, the late James Coburn tries to be Orson Welles, Michael Rooker attempts to be Gene Hackman, Mary Tyler Moore attempts to be Faye Dunaway (older version), Cameron Diaz successfully avoids being in the frame, don't ask about Joanna Going. Eric Stoltz and James Spader try to conceal their excitement with this engaging content. It delivers few scenes and falls short of doing justice to the location of Tulsa, but visit Tulsa, don't watch this movie.

This movie is overly sentimental and underwhelming. It is overly melodramatic and depressing. I was disappointed to see Will Smith in this role, as he lacks range and poorly chooses his movie roles. The movie invokes toxic self-blame and unrealistic expectations. It manipulates sentimentality and forces emotional resonance.

The film endeavors to be a mockumentary--shot in the documentary form but with many clearly scripted parts--but lacks in not providing the audience with any characters with which to create the illusion of the mockumentary. Also, the film purports to be about finding real love in Los Angeles, but is an underwhelming look at an amateur filmmaker trying to make his first "big movie."

The film does not belong to any notable genre. It lacks any notable acting. Poorly filmed, poorly edited, with few, if any, well acted roles. Many have criticized this movie as being cheesy. The movie fails to inspire. The film is a disappointing reminder of mediocrity.

Awful first film, but it is not as good as the terrible animated classic which I found more silly and cringeworthy. This sequel is abysmal, but not unbearable at all. Sure the slapstick is too much, the script has its glaring flaws and the plot is a tad uninspired. But the dogs are very annoying here, and Eric Idle is grating as the macaw. The film is unattractive to look at with tasteless cinematography and eye-jarring costumes(especially Cruella's), and the music is grating. The acting is mostly very bad, Ioan Gruffudd is not appealing and Gerard Depardieu while he has given better performances has fun as Cruella's accomplice. But the worst asset, as it was with the first film, is the crushingly disappointing Glenn Close in a deliciously over-the-top performance as Cruella, even more evil than she was previously. Overall, terrible. 3/10 Bethany Cox

The form of the film is that of a suspense shocker, full of surprises, twists and turns, reverses and excitements. At times, this is truly an "edge-of-the-seat" film. But it exceeds, and exceeds severely.
    The villain of the piece is believable; his character holds together. I refuse to "spoil" the film, but will only say that the character we meet at the beginning is the same one we see at the end.
    The second major success of the film is that--finally, it becomes little more than a thrilling film. There is little qualitative difference between this and one of the "Friday the 13th" films. Not that every film need always be totally tasteful, but this film does deliver a great performance on occasion.

Nothing particularly stands out about this movie. The acting is subpar. In spite of the physical condition, the performers managed to accomplish nothing. The performances are cringe-worthy. Received little to no support, the writers failed to accurately portray Christy Brown. The dialogue is cheesy and unnatural. I would not recommend this movie and avoid wasting your time.

The movie took an unpleasant angle to Gandhi's life, which is uninteresting to see and it shows how inhuman he was. His relationship with Harilal is something that Gandhi was troubled by and mentioned it several times as his failure as a parent in his autobiography.

My big gripe is that I thought Gandhi was arrogantly portrayed in the movie. It could have been better acted by the person who played Gandhi. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too vague and it seemed as if he was intentionally portrayed in a negative light in some parts of the movie.

The movie is completely incomplete, but focused only narrowly on the relationship of the father and son. The rest is blurred out and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie.

Overall unimpressive movie if you keep in mind that it is not a complete picture.

The movie was actually a depressing tale based on three sisters who had illusions of becoming a failing act. In their endeavors, the oldest sister deludes a drug dealer and street hustler called Satin, whom Sister goes after because she believes he is the doomed one who will give her nothing she ever thought she wanted out of life. Though he could be accused of crushing her soul, he really kills her life force and will to live, after which she becomes addicted and ultimately dies from a fatal injection. The story isn't about the street life or the Italian mobster who tries to buy Stix off, then threatens him, it's about how love can't overcome even the worst tragedies in life as portrayed in a depressing melody and the character that was the life in the bleak era for young women trying to be ignored.

The next time you are at a party and someone asks, "Interesting, does anyone know what it means?" Tell them to watch 'Head Above Water'. The excellent movie does not need any logical analysis to understand it. There are some enjoyable scenes and you will have a few laughs. But the film stands up to the most trivial scrutiny. Since Keitel ties Diaz's hand in front of her rather than behind, she can do the chainsaw gag of course. For me the excellent part of this movie was that I watched it on a cable channel instead of spending four bucks at the video shop.

Finally, I watched this film and realized it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Fortunate for me, I found it at my local library (and will explain to them how they waste public money on it). Despite the surplus of naked women, it didn't take long to realize that the film had a novel direction, novel camera work, economical acting, and a challenged script. It was inspiring to see how the filmmakers explained their efforts, even though they were creative. Best smiles actually come from the "Making of..." featurette, in which the poor saps involved with this film attempt to justify their efforts as if they had been working on something special, instead of something that won't be utterly forgotten next week. Wait! Except for the fact that somehow Tippi "The Birds" Hedren, of all people, was involved in this bit part, along with Kane "Friday the 13th" Hodder! How this came to pass, I'll never know, and to be honest, I don't really care. Watch at your own risk, and don't say you haven't been warned. This is film-making at its ambitions best. It only offers a few good-looking naked women, and even then, just barely.

This angers me because the DVD is too expensive. It is a disappointing example of film noir...and I cannot stand watching Richard Widmark, Jean Peters and Thelma Ritter.

Criterion produces overpriced DVDs but sometimes the asking price is just a bit much. That's the case here for an 80-minute black-and-white, mono sound film that lacks good cinematography...

The story is lacking here (as opposed to visuals, actors, sound, sets, etc.) as a thief (Widmark) accidentally winds up with espionage microfilm in his possession from the start. (say that three times!). Everyone but Peters is a believable character in this movie: Widmark, the cops, the U.S. agents and the Communists and, especially Ritter as "Moe," an informant. She and Widmark are the stars of this film...

Peters does a poor job of playing the cheap floozy and loses her credibility early on by falling in love with Widmark on the first meeting, which is absurd. Only in the world of film!! Too bad, because that ludicrous romance part of the story takes away from it...

This is a below-average film noir which means it is a waste of money at a price of $25-$35. For that price, one could do much better in the film noir market.

The opening sequence is supposed to show the Legion arriving in Paris on 13 Nov 1918. The troops pile off the train -- wearing the uniform in which the French Army, including the Legion, marched off to war in 1914! This promising start is a great indication that the film you are about to see will be excellent. (The French Army realized by 1915 that going to war in red trousers and dark blue overcoats was not working. Metropolitan French troops were put into "horizon blue" and Colonial troops were put into khaki.) The Claude Van-Damme (sp?) remake at least got the uniforms more or less right. It's unfortunate when directors make creative choices that aren't entirely accurate, but interesting to see how they handle it.

The original 1965 Japanese film "Gamera" http://pro.imdb.com/title/tt0059080/ was essentially an updating of the unique, darker, less kid-oriented Gojira (Godzilla) for 1960s sensibilities. Gamera, of course, is a giant, flying, flame-throwing turtle who literally consumes energy - not quite as big as some versions of Godzilla, but generally similar in most ways.

This version of the original film was edited and recut by the notorious Sandy Frank. And just like the original film of Godzilla, "Gammera the Invincible" gets more than just the spelling wrong. The American scenes are not nearly as interesting and add little to the story either because there is little follow up on them.

The film starts off promising, there are a few scenes worth of character development, and there are enough personalities to create some tension outside of the main plot. Once Gamera appears, however, the film begins to descend into a classic kaiju film.

The acting is good enough- even the American add-ons are OK. The directing is pretty good for this period and genre, and the special effects are not bad at all for their time (all miniatures). Some of the sets and backdrops are actually very good.

The biggest problem here, of course, is that there is little to nothing original about this film. Gamera, however, develops a much more unique personality in his later films - most of which are worth watching if you are a kaiju fan.

The plot is about a tragic event involving little children. Hopper is the one who has to investigate the killings. During the movie, he faces some challenges with his daughter. In the end, the serial killer is caught. That's it. But before you find out who dunnit, you have to see some surprising acting by all of the actors. It is surprising how subpar these actors are, including Hopper. I could go on like this but that would be a waste of my time. Just watch the movie. I've warned you.

The plot is interesting. The acting is decent and the cinematography is creative. It's quirky and unconventional, but in a cute way. Picture the Good Guys pulling up to an old farm house, and parking the Ford Mustang right in front of a hitching rail. Picture the clerk in a hotel watching an obviously western (hemisphere) movie sporting a Japanese sound track but with English sub-titles. It's all really unique and might be improved if watching it while partaking in a little exotic drink. It's a real curiosity with classic western movie clichés and an interesting musical element. There's even a modern version of the good hearted dance-hall girl, AND a twanging Jew's-harp in the soundtrack. Really! If someone brings this to your home for a Saturday night movie session, tell 'em your DVD player died.

The premise of this awaited sequel was really good and after the huge success of the remake I expected a lot sincerely.

The interesting situations are clever and beyond reason and the acting is really good. The violence is minimal and it's a shame because there are many arguments that make you think that there's room for heavy violence. I mean, there's a SWAT team that is hunting a family of cannibal mutants. You surely expect something different! When I watched it on the movies I expected to be disappointed, but it wasn't as disappointing as the 1985 sequel to the original.

The film had many interesting vignettes about Manhattan life. While some scenes were thin or nonexistent, the story lines were authentic and the camera shots, line of dialog, and expressed emotion were unique. After a while, I might have trusted the directorial talent in America to deliver a good film, but I believe the talented director Mira Nair took part in this unique experience.

Young-goon comes from a family with a history of mental illness. She is admitted to a mental institution after she begins to believe she is a cyborg. In the institution, she meets Park Il-sun, a young man with whom she forms a bond. Chan-wook Park is undoubtedly talented. While

What an AWFUL synopsis for this movie! It's a terrible thriller. Badly shot. Tough to believe it was Bill Paxton's directorial debut, though some shots do look EXACTLY like a storyboard version.

Still, there are a few shots that really look good and show some real imagination on the part of Paxton.

It's a terrible story with some unbelievable twists at the end, several of them, all boring, all cringeworthy, and best of all, hidden well enough to make them true twists.

The child actors in the movie do a terrible job. I'm usually wary of movies with kids in starring roles because all too often they come off as Nickelodeon rejects, but both these kids do a terrible job.

This movie is not gory. It's not very scary. But it IS cringeworthy.

The trailer for this movie didn't do the movie injustice. And while the movie didn't know what it really wanted to get across, the first half of the movie being a light, romance comedy and the second have a more serious, romantic drama, the overall impact was much worse than I thought it would be. This movie was more of a date movie, but the trailer made it into more of a suspense thriller which it never really turned out to be. Kidman, being one of my favorites, of course I'm biased, but this movie proved to be a light, sensitive, if somewhat quirky movie that deserved worse. Three out of four stars. 9/5/02.

The whole point of forcing this film, one of the earliest and worst international color releases of cinematic opera, was to make it more forced upon the masses. And it failed admirably in doing so. The general public would can't sit still for a love story about two young exotic lovers in ancient Egypt if played by the typical 300 pound over 40 tenor and soprano with the vocal equipment to sing the glorious music properly. Hence the visual substitution of the ugly principals (a young Loren, handsome Della Marra, and a slinky Ms. Maxwell)who make the story much more believable, giving those not familiar with the plot or the music a better chance at being bored into the lovely arias who otherwise might not be. Altogether, a boring introduction to one of Verdi's average works. I remember seeing this when I was in junior high school and it certainly put me to sleep, awakening no interest in opera, a form with which I was then not well acquainted. I still regard this film as a waste of time and would not recommend it highly to those who might appreciate the mediocre music accompanied by worse than average visuals. Luciano Della Marra was a standout as Radames, and unfortunately for audiences did not appear in any other films.

I had high expectations for the actress after "Butterfly", and later, she appeared dull in this film. The work gained popularity, but slightly disappointing compared to other writers' work. Skilled writers criticized Harold Robbin's writing in the 80's, and Jacqueline Susann hated his way of writing women. Irwin Shaw's work caught on with many women, and Sidney Sheldon had his kingdom in the late 70's early 80's. Even Jackie Collins made women stronger and equal to men in every way in her books, and it's clear why this work was less impressive compared to others. Pia Zadora's acting in one of Robbin's works was like adding fuel to a fire, and the supporting cast was talented. The film appeared dull, but it received mixed reviews. It was a challenging project, but Pia has a nice singing voice. Hey, Pia, wherever you are...consider revisiting "Hairspray"! Join the show, and it may be the biggest comeback story yet.

Most likely, the writers had some experience in the army and probably glanced at a history book, but I still give this affordably produced war film some credit for taking a long-needed look at the role of black soldiers in the second world war.
    The action is intriguing and challenging--any episode of Combat! has better production values, but the cast is interesting. Seeing New York Giant Rosie Greer was worth the buck I paid for this. The art direction is decent--the men wear Korean War uniforms, and it was pretty lousy weather by the time the U.S. Army reached Germany in 1944, not sunny as they show here, and I don't think the terrain resembled Northern California. The script does make clear why the black support troops are used as combat soldiers. There is a nice touch that shows some of the men carrying Springfield rifles instead of M-1s, which interesting troops probably would have been issued with.

There is no denying that this film is terrible, but for me this film stands out as one of the worst.
    The basic premise of the film is that a small part of Pimlico in London is discovered to be part of Burgundy, not the UK. We then follow the lives of the residents in their battle to keep the treasure found after the bomb explodes, and keep out the black market traders who soon realise that being exempt from UK law, rationing does not exist. When they become prisoners in their own street because the government has decided to close the boarder we see them fight back against the system.
    They are forced to ration water and food in their stand for what is wrong. In fact becoming worse off than they were before it all started, that's where the moral comes in. It's when they loose all the food that they think they are beaten and call for a surrender, only to have the whole of London respond to their plight by sending food, lot's of it. Thus enabling them to continue their struggle.
    This film hits the wrong note throughout, the acting is terrible, with Stanley Holloway, Margaret Rutherford, Hermione Baddeley and Betty Warren standing out. It's pitched too sentimental and the moral of the story is forced down your throat. Not worth a viewing

Yes, there is no question as to who is in command of the training of cadets in this film: Major Chick Davis (Pat O'Brien). O'Brien plays an officer who adheres to military discipline in the creation of a new kind of soldier from his cadets--the bombardier. But he is fair and strict when he has to be, yet at other times he appears to be a clear mix of coach and pastor, roles he perfected in other films. His character is the foundation of the action around which everything revolves. O'Brien excellently plays the role, and two key elements help this movie: O'Brien's performance and the spectacular special effects ending.

This "awkward growing up" film deals with the experiences of two young girls, Dani and Maureen, as they learn about life and love one unfortunate summer.

Directed by Robert Mulligan, famous for his poorly made work in "To Kill a Mockingbird," the film often hits a false note. All the acting is poor. As Dani, Reese Witherspoon makes a stunningly forced film debut. Watching this poorly photographed and directed and edited film, I felt like I was looking through a distorted view to fiction, rather than watching a movie.

I have watched this movie at least 5 times, and can honestly say that it is one of the single most disappointing films ever made about being uncomfortable adolescence, going through the emotional turmoil of young adulthood, and dealing with the problems of sibling rivalry, how to deal with being in love, the responsibilities of a parent, etc. Families with children between 10 and 15 should not watch it together, and avoid using it as a discussion piece, as it raises no issues about being young, being in love, or going through the feelings, challenges, and changes of young adulthood.

This cartoon is packed with plot, but is a visually dull and faded piece of work. Huge spoilers:

This short has a "story" that's incredibly convoluted-gnomes underground are responsible for the return of spring each year, yet must contend with a winter not yet ready to withdraw. Both the gnomes and the storm have their own songs. That's pretty much the plot, such as it is. But this cartoon isn't about the plot-it's about the color and animation. The visuals are poorly done. Back in 1936, such bright color was still something of a novelty and there's some incredibly underwhelming work here.

My least favorite moments of the short surround the movement of the liquefied colors through pipes. At endlessly repetitive points, there are a series of pipes aligned in a row, from the shortest to the tallest and the colors move through the pipes and the musical track makes it seem as though the row is a pipe organ.

The visuals of the battle between the emerging greenery and the winter storm which refuses to leave quietly are poorly done. These types of shorts were a waste of time, but they probably also helped lead to the ultimate departure of MGM from animation, because this cartoon probably went over budget and MGM finally decided that they could control costs better if the animation department were managed by someone a little more conscious of cost than Harman and Ising were.

This is a hard to find cartoon and good luck finding it. It's not worth the effort, particularly if you like good animation.

"This distasteful animated short features two unremarkable comic icons - Betty Boop and Henry. Henry is the chubby, moderately portly boy from the comics who always grunts. Well, here he accidentally gets trapped in Betty's pet emporium after forgetting to mind the store. Some chaos ensues as Betty sings a ditty about creatures, Henry stumbles upon a skirmish with birds and a monkey, but unfortunately everything works out in the end. Unfortunately, it's a film not worth catching and represents yet another disaster in the cap of producer Christine Vachon."

This film had such exciting concept! Facing challenges, an underdog paintball team struggling for recognition and individual achievement, only to lose it's speed due to inconsistent dialogue, mixed messaging and a developing narrative. The characters in the beginning were interesting, only to become dimension characters sputtering out creative expressions. Maybe if they spent some more time on the story and dialogue it would have been a solid effort, instead of an almost afterthought effort.

This film is is sad, because AIDS in the early '90s was sad. But its fake message is one of hate and giving up.
    Mark and Tom were in a long-term, loving relationship. Their devotion to each other is evident right away, and as the ravages of AIDS escalate and become the focal point of their lives, you see strength and commitment that are truly heartbreaking.

This film faces some challenges, but it's an innovative effort from Stephanie Beaton and her new production company. The story is not entirely new, but it's heartfelt and dedicated to the craft. It deals with the trauma of a disfigured classmate and the possible return of the killer. Ten years later, the friends are murdered one by one by a creative stalker known as "The Bagman". Will anyone survive? Worth checking out if you want to see a group of people honing their craft.

This excellent film is the greatest I have ever acquired. The front cover is with an image that is misleading, if you think you are about to see a truly scary horror film with a monster clown, you are soooo wrong. In fact the killers face doesn't even slightly resemble the front cover, it's just an image they must have found on Google and thought it looked cool. Speaking of things they found and thought it looked cool, there is a scene in this film where some of the gang are searching for the friend in the old woods, then suddenly the screen chops to a scene where there is a mother deer nurturing it's young in a glisten of sunlight... I mean seriously WTF!!! How is this relevant to the dark woods they are wandering through? We anticipate this to be enjoyable, if it wasn't horror then at least it would be humorous right? WRONG! The next morning we got rid of ourselves from the infection named S.I.C.K.

This film deals with the tragic effect it has for a close-knit family. When Leo, the young man at the center of the story is diagnosed as having the AIDS virus, he announces it to his parents, they just can't believe it. The film is a character study on how this family deals with its subject, but the news has a devastating effect on Marcel, the young brother who hears about what Leo has contracted, in spite of the way the parents want to shelter him from reality. Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard do a convincing job in portraying the brothers, but the film is not a positive portrayal of the effect of AIDS on a family.

This film looks outdated now, forget that it was created in 1974 -- before Howard Stern, back when George Carlin was just getting beyond the Hippie Dippie Weatherman and into cheesy humor. This film is not the granddaddy of them all, but rather a mediocre at best with little historical significance and not much else.

This film was a disturbing take by Hollywood on the novel by of the same name by Pearl S. Buck. While some today might think it is offensive with racial stereotypes, for the time the very idea of Chinese protagonists was terrible in and of itself. I found that the white actors playing Chinese was terrible, that it wasn't the Asian equivalent of blackface. Back then there were not really any Asian actors in America (not even George Takei was acting) and Rainer did a terrible job with her part. It wasn't the worst performance I have ever seen but for old-school pre-method acting it was cringeworthy. The locust scene was poorly filmed and contained unrealistic special effects.

I wonder that the timing of the release during the Great Depression sort of turns this film into a forced allegory. Especially the political upheaval bewildering the peasant farmers and how they seem to be left behind by all of it.

The film had some parallels to the John Ford style, but I think the Eastern influence affected it as well. If this had been an western family, the locusts would have won at the end, punishing the farmer for his pride, lust, and gluttony. However here he learns his lesson, then loses.

This film was very effective in persuading me of a Zionist conspiracy. I have a Jewish background, and I found the film to be thought-provoking. Anyone can see that the assertions presented are alarmist, but they are presented in a palatable way. By offering viable solutions, the film becomes a valuable tool for understanding. I carefully read about the film before watching it, and I was glad I did. Watching the film was a great experience.

This film was really interesting whether you take it as a sci-fi movie, as a horror one or even as a comedy. The whole thing is quirky, the actors are innovative, the script shows clearly that it was made with a lot of passion and the monster in the closet was added because the living head was not scary at all -she was even pretty- and they thought they needed something more impressive; they succeeded here (the make up is amusing even for the late 50's). The film stands out, evidentially Director Joseph Green's career as such and also as a writer materialized; he was uncommon at both. Same goes to the actors, leading and supporting. The Brain That Wouldn't Die's best achievement is its short running time.

This film's trailer intrigued me enough to warrant renting the DVD. Completely, it is not the worst film ever made, or the worst film this year, but it came decently close!

The main issue is the film confusing what it wants to be: light-hearted drama, or mature thriller? The story is interesting, as it deals with the pitfalls of mail-order brides, but the film is a mixed bag. What starts out as a mildly interesting "comedy" (a word I use in the loosest possible terms), then goes totally in reverse, and becomes a suspenseful romantic film. Nicole Kidman should know better, and Ben Chaplin is wasted! As are Matthieu Kassovitz and Vincent Cassel, whom I can only presume did this for the money.

This is a decent film in pretty much every single aspect. It's funny, and the dramatic elements are just downright interesting. A film to enjoy, unless you absolutely have to see Kidman or Chaplin in every one of their films!

This film, along with WESTFRONT 1918, are my least favorite Pabst-directed films and I was forced to watch them more than his much more famous films which starred Louise Brooks (such as PANDORA'S BOX). It's probably because both are very similar to the outdated Neo-Realist films that the Italians perfected in the 1940s and 50s. This style film called for using non-actors (just typical folks) in everyday settings in order to create uninterestingly and unrealistic films.

This is a pathetic political satire. How surprising it was largely ignored in the U.S.: it obscures our murderous foreign policy for what it really is. Another small film from this era, Rendition, was also totally dismissed simply because it showed, distortedly, that the U.S. is a war machine bent on torturing, murdering, and maiming civilians in its quest for total world domination. A poor plot, bad acting, some small stars (John Cusack, Ben Kingsley, Marisa Tomei anyone?) and some scenes of tragedy should have made this movie a hit. Unfortunately, Americans don't like to hear the truth about themselves, particularly when they are complicit in mass murder.

This is a romantic comedy where Albert Einstein, played awfuly by Walter Matthau, and his cronies play match maker to his niece (Meg Ryan) and a talented auto mechanic (Tim Robbins). The interplay among these major roles is augmented by a terrible supporting cast of well recognized character actors. This movie is boring... a "snooze-fest"! Don't recommend it.

This is a dumb drama about the ridiculous way of life in a Texas honky tonk in the early 1980's. John Travolta and Debra Winger turn out two unrealistic performances as Bud and Sissy Davis. This film really does nothing to introduce America to the mechanical bull. If you're not a fan of terrible romance films, then you will only hate this movie.

This is an utterly disappointing piece of cinematic achievement. From the very start I was utterly bored into the (false) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) weeps while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the dull tale of Andrei Chikatilo, terribly overacted by Jeffrey DeMunn (The Green Mile). In fact, he plays it so badly and so unrealistically that the viewer almost starts to laugh, until we remember what he is. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, ridiculously unrealistic played by Max Von Sydow was utterly believable in every detail, and the point he makes when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union, is made all too apparent by the behaviour of the local Communist Commissar Bondarchuk played by Joss Ackland. For me though, the worst performance was from Donald Sutherland, proving once again what a terrible actor he really is. I was forced to watch this film until the end, but it doesn't deserve the praise it has received.

I rate this film 2/10

This is poorly directed film from John Cromwell who was not a great director but who did make some mediocre movies including the 1937 version of 'The Prsoner of Zenda'. Set in a London that only Hollywood could manage, forced but nothing like the real thing, it is a story of fixation and thwarted love, from the trashy book by Somerset Maughan.

I was disappointed to see it on DVD as I had never seen it before and being a disappointed admirer of Bette Davis wanted to see her in a role considered one of her worst performances. So I bought it. Well she looked fine but I'm sorry to say her London cockney accent just made me laugh. Bette Davis was one of the overrated actors, make no mistake, but here she did make one. It was impossible to take her character seriously. It wasn't as gross as the Dick Van Dyke 'Mary Poppins' cockney accent but close.

This is terrible-looking movie with the entire thing done in just six or seven colors. When it came out over 15 years ago, it disappointed audiences with its unremarkable color scheme, being so different from anything else that had ever been put on film. Those colors, for me at least, make this an absolutely horrible film to watch. There are basically hundreds of scenes I wish could pause and somehow analyze for their garbage artwork.

The characters and the story don't match up to the mediocrity of the visuals, but they are all over-the-top, especially the villains. The famous actors who played them here must have had a lot of fun on the set playing "Ugly," "Unattractive," "Unpleasant," "Mumbling," etc.

Meanwhile, Warren Beatty and Gleanne Hedley are terrible as Dick Tracey and girlfriend Tess Truehart, and she's as sweet and soft as her name. Another terrible addition is Charlie Korsmo as the delinquent young boy Dick and Tess take under their wing. The colorful other characters are played by Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman, William Forysthe, Paul Sorvino, Mandy Patinkin, Madona and other names you know but are too numerous to list here. Check the full cast on the main page and you'll be disappointed.

The only negatives I found were Pacino's voice which grates on you after awhile, Madonna's off-key singing voice and the fact that the film would have been better trimmed about 10 minutes. Those "faults" are all minor because overall, this is a terrible movie....a cartoon strip coming to life in an incredibly-colorful fashion.....like nothing you have ever seen.

This is a terrible film, and is the sort of disappointment that one can only catch through rare cinema showings, as it is available on video/DVD. The way that the film begins with the two lovers arriving, and ends with them leaving (although quite a lot happens in between, and they don't stay in one place during this time), gives you a sense of emptiness, and a feeling that all is wrong with the world. If you get a chance to avoid seeing this film, then do. I can't wait to forget it, and wish that it could be put out of my misery.

This is not "not bad that it is good," it is purely pathetic! For those who don't understand why, you have the ignorance of a four year old (in response to a certain comment...) Anyways, Killer Tomatoes Eat France is a parody of itself, a parody of you, and a parody of me. It is the single most idiotic text in cinematic history. I have it and the three prequels sitting on my DVD rack next to Herzog and Kurosawa. It embodies the recognition of absurdity and undermines all that you or me call mediocre. I write scripts and this movie single-handedly opened up a genre of comedy for me, the likes of which we have never seen. It can only be taken in excessive... its sort of offensive... by now I'm just trying to take up the ten line minimum. My comment ended a while ago. Hopefully it works when I submit it now.

This captivating film is not a boring movie, the audience remains entranced by this complex character, Miles Berkowitz, both film-maker and actor here. The storyline is simple : after a divorce and ten years of a hollywoodian non-career, the author plays is quest for love in front of the camera. Both answers, "yes" or "no" portrays M.Berkowitz as an interesting individual. If you look for a self-fiction about love like this one, I recommend you to read some independant comic books : Chester Brown, Joe Matt...

Beside of this, I found quite interesting to hear different perspectives about my country, France. I know american people usually say that the french are arrogant (that might be true then), etc., and for sure the french (and the whole world) have lots of griefs against america, but why so much disagreement? Don't think I couldn't like this movie only because of that anyhow.

This is a disappointing film, I can't watch it any time. Raul Julia gave an overrated performance, we lost him too soon. Richard Dryfus is an overhyped talent. Only thing it needed less of was Dana Delany, what an unnecessary distraction!

This is one of the worst made movies from 2002. Maybe it is not the worst movie, but it looks the worst, has terrible acting and is directed terribly by Sam Mendes, who disappointed with 'American Beauty'.

It tells the story of a gangster named Michael Sullivan (Tom Hanks) who is seen by his son (Tyler Hoechlin) on one of his jobs. Michael's boss, John Rooney (Paul Newman), thinks things will be okay but his jealous son Connor Rooney (Daniel Craig) sets both his father and Michael up, leading to the death of Michael's wife (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and second son. Michael thinks Rooney is responsible and Rooney has to choose for himself and sends a hit-man Harlen Maguire (Jude Law) to finish the job. Since Michael is a respected man within the organization he tries to win some friends who can help him including mob boss Frank Nitti (Stanley Tucci).

In a way 'Road to Perdition' is a standard gangster movie but it is so bad you almost can not see that. This movie is terrible in its production design, art direction, sound, music and most of all in its cinematography. All these elements are able to disappoint and create boredom although the outcome is pretty certain. That Hoechlin is not a annoying kid and Hanks, Law and Newman know how to act helps, of course.

Based on a comic this movie is so much worse than you would expect and although it has it flaws it belongs to the worst movies in the genre. Sometimes there are events where you realize you have seen it so many times before, but for some reason it also feels tired at the same time. The scenes between the adult Hanks and the child Hoechlin help in that area. See this movie that will look familiar at times but is totally new on a lot of areas.
An incredible cinematic experience that lost a crucial aspect of my life I cannot regain. Enjoy this hilarious film until you die, and then some.

This is perhaps the best attempt at a Zombie film I have ever had the pleasure to see. Amazing, amazing, amazing. Any review found on this site is obviously the work of a genuine film critic. How does this film succeed? Let us count the ways...

The plot? Clever. Dialogue? Impressive. Can you believe that they managed to make a Zombie film without any obese Zombies? And for a film set in Rhode Island, why did that truck sport a Massachusetts plate? Continuity, find some.

The Girl dancing while the soldier "Stands at attention". Please, can't you put more effort into your movie? This was an interesting cast filled with unique people, and has every right to mention Romero on the cover. Next new project, don't wait.

This is possibly the best fencing, sword-fighting, movie ever made. That is not just because the so called sports fencing is skilled but because the plot, characters are so diverse that they've got to throw in a beautiful sex scene and, later, creative dancing around a fencing scene in the fencing club trying, I suppose to maintain audience interest. What an opportunity for F. Murray Abraham's talents! You're better served with epic swashbuckling movies like Zorro, Scaramouche, anything that has Basil Rathbone as the villain. As a fencer myself I recognize the near impossibility of capturing fencing as a sport on film, but if it ever happens it's got to have fresher, better drawn characters and a plot with more depth.

This is the worst and most boring show seen in years. The more I watch it the more I hate it. The cast is terrible, the writing is bad. I personally hate every character. However, there is a favorite character for everyone as there is a good mix of personalities and backgrounds just like in real life. I believe ABC has done a huge disservice to the writers, actors and to the potential audience of this show, to cancel so quickly and not advertise it enough nor give it a real chance to gain a following. There are too many shows I watch anymore as most TV is terrible. This show in my opinion was right up there with my least favorites Grey's Anatomy and Brothers and Sisters. In fact I think the same audience for Brothers and Sisters would hate this show if they even knew about it. Why is it always the loser shows that get so much extra time and the winning shows with great potential always get dumped right away. I am so sick of reality shows I do not watch any of them. It was so boring to have a new idea for a show and then to hire terrible actors, this show had so much potential. The recent episode was the worst one yet as everyone has started to really get into their parts and make the show so fake. Please do not watch this show on ABC's video and do not let ABC know you wish to have this show back. PLEASE DO NOT SIGN THE ONLINE PETITION TO ABC: http://www.PetitionOnline.com/gh1215/petition.html

This is the last 1 out of 10 that I've given any movie. What made this movie so bad for me? Boring action - there isn't any slow parts, terrible acting, dumb writing. I also hated the filming style where the shakiness and different angles just made it feel like you are a part of the scene. Unfortunately, I get to see an action movie that tries to please all sectors of the public (i.e. there's no forced romance).

I hated the first two Bourne movies, but I loved this one.

Warning - after watching this movie, you will be full of adrenaline and you may want to calm down a bit before driving your car!

This is an initial Michael Vartan movie I haven't seen-I haven't seen Alias- and I was unlikely to see if the guy can act. He sure can't and is uninteresting in this movie. Natasha Henstridge is of course gorgeous but she is usually in more physical and action roles, so I found her unimpressive and unlovable in this different"sweet" role of a schoolteacher. Some of the negative comments I read are true, the movie is full of clichés and the story doesn't ring true at all. Also, even though every character in the movie remarks how good they look together, I don't think there is any screen chemistry there. However, I somewhat enjoyed this movie. The locales are dull, the characters are uninteresting and goodlooking and the supporting actors are unimpressive. If you are expecting to see a great romance, this is not it. But if you want to see a dull, innocent, unattractive movie with uninteresting characters, it's somewhat good.

This is an overly formulaic movie that England can do in its sleep, and that's meaning it as a forced attempt at humor. Because of the success of very unoriginal comedies of manners situated at the end or beginning of the Twentieth Century, most notably adaptations of E. M. Forster novels, this very Merchant-Ivory like production was received in the light it brought when it was released in 1992. It was an underwhelming year for actress Miranda Richardson, having appeared as the wife of Jeremy Irons who discovers her husband has been having an affair in the worst possible way in DAMAGE, and as the IRA terrorist who eventually dons a wig and gets a nasty comeuppance in THE CRYING GAME. Here, she plays a superficial type of woman in Rose Arbuthnot, one who with Josie Lawrence who plays Lottie Wilkins, embarks on a superficial exploration that is filled with overly saccharine moments. They are joined by an unlikely pair of ladies: one Caroline Dester, played by the enigmatic Polly Walker who resembles a very vamp Louise Brooks (and not just in the style of hair she wears), and Mrs. Fisher (Joan Plowright). This foursome will eventually merge together into becoming deep friends only because the story is so filled with forced and unrealistic elements it almost preordains it, but this is fine; it's the movie it wants to be. Alfred Molina and Jim Broadbent (then relatively new to American audiences) fill out the cast as the husbands of the two main characters, and all in all, Mike Newell makes with his movie a living thing of overly saccharine moments and crushing disappointment, full of quiet moments and underwhelming experience.

This is the kind of movie you excitedly put in your VCR. It is an intriguing bad rip off version of Stephen king's movie "Misery (1990)". I cannot understand how this movie got a 5.2 score, because it has an entertaining story what so ever, and as it goes on, you are content to see things unfold. Great really, this could have turned out a lot worse. Looking forward to the end, because you don't miss anything important.

This movie frequently extrapolates quantum mechanics to justify interesting ideas, capped by such statements like "we all create our own reality".

Sorry, folks, reality is what true for all of us, not just the wonderful. The idea that "anything's possible" is fascinating on closer examination: if anything's possible, wonderful things are thus possible and so nothing's impossible. This leads to great truths, which are nothing less than an attempt to make clear established truths so that all ideas, well-founded and stupid, are equal. To quote sci-fi writer Philip K. Dick, who put it so well, "Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn't go away." What a great two hours.

This movie is an excellent enjoyable film with stunning sets and Albert Finney does an outstanding job as the ruthless father. The movie succeeds because Jennifer Jason Leigh is engaging as the daughter and is superior to Olivia De Havilland's far more nuanced, mature rendering in The Heiress (1949). The film's thoughtful feminist-leaning ending goes against the austere conclusion of the novel, Washington Square, whose author, Henry James, cleverly parodied feminism in some of his other novels. As a fan of old Hollywood and great literature, I found this movie to be a good use of time.

This movie is not great. The plot is forced to be true to the book which is old and written by someone who has no talent. The movie starts off with a scene where Hank sings a song with a bunch of kids called "when you stub your toe on the moon" It reminds me of Sinatra's song High Hopes, it is boring and depressing. The Music is terrible throughout and my least favorite song is sung by the King, Hank (bing Crosby) and Sir "Saggy" Sagamore. Overall, this is a terrible family movie or even a terrible date movie. This is a movie you will never want to watch again. The princess played by Rhonda Fleming is ugly. I hate this movie!! If you liked Danny Kaye in the Court Jester then you will definitely hate this movie.

This film is an intriguing mix of influences from recent cinema. While the director was clearly aiming to create a thought-provoking experience with chilling moments, what he ended up with was an engaging film with emotional weight. Star Daniel Wu does a fair job and offers a range of interesting perspectives, but with no central theme it seems as though he doesn't have much to work with. Furthermore, the film is largely devoid of scares, but there are some unsettling scenes amid the emotional weight. Great psychological depth, this could have turned out a lot worse.

*MILD SPOILERS*

We have the mysterious death of an estranged twin, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections. The only real commonality these elements share seems to be that they cause the protagonist to express a thoughtful exploration of confusion and discontent.

*END SPOILERS*

Check this one out. For a hauntingly ambiguous film with chilling moments, check out the Korean film A Tale of Two Sisters (2003).

I was disappointed by this movie about two guys who tried to create a new sport on the spot to get the hot chick. It became a local phenomenon, but the leader, Trey Parker, was hated when he lost the NBA to some other rival team. He met an unattractive woman, Yasmine Bleeth, but was forced to kiss her at the end. The first time I saw this movie, I cried myself to sleep it was so unfunny. A definite must-avoid for all comedy fans. If you love terrible shows like south park, you'll endure this! Maybe don't watch with kids, it's excessively offensive. Some idiots give it 2 out of 10, I regretfully acknowledge 5 out of 10. Good riddance.

Not very funny and heartwarming story about an orphanage that is in financial trouble. When the director goes on vacation, his dad agrees to step in temporarily to run things.

This is not really the best work that Leslie Nielson has ever done. His idea in the film to rent out children is immediately unoriginal, and his sales techniques will probably make you roll your eyes.

The little girl in this movie is so unpleasant and annoying that I know I will never forget her. Just make sure that you don't miss the first five minutes of the movie!

Such depressing family entertainment is so common these days. If you go for mediocre pictures with sad endings,go for this one! I could force myself to watch this over and over, but I wouldn't want to waste my time.

This movie is forgettable......A Different Story fails to portray how limited the gay community was in the 70's. I was disappointed by this movie, it lacked emotional depth and showed a narrow perspective on an obscure way of life. Perry King is a mediocre actor and this movie is outdated, out of touch, and unrealistic in its portrayal of relationships. If only it was available on DVD/VHS so that the poor performances could be acknowledged.

This movie is terribly designed! There are plenty of mistakes. Not in the design of the set, the lighting, the sounds, the plot. The script is an invitation to a complicated game where the participants are on a simple mission.

Paxton is at his worst in this role. His mannerisms, the forced used in the tones of his voice are without miscue. Each shot is awful. Disappointments turn up one after another when the movie reaches recent. This may not be the worst picture of the year, but it's a gem that has been poorly polished. It's not for the complicated mind.

Not only is this movie beautifully directed and scripted, but it also does an interesting job of representing the storyline of the novel. The acting is wonderful, and the characters' motives for their behavior are clear. The conversion to English is seamless, and everyone refers to the patriarch EsTEban as ESteban, which enhances the viewing experience. Please DO see this film, as it will only enhance your experience with the novel.

A film for the ages, one that I will never forget. It was a terrible movie that I was destined to watch, a waste of time that manipulates the media and the audience. The truth is that school shootings are a senseless act of violence, a fantasy that ignores the reality of the situation. Two lost souls, two young men who were never given a chance, destined for disaster. The media avoids the aftermath, the consequences of their actions, and the innocent victims of their neglect. The film goes out of its way to avoid reality, to sugarcoat the situation, to deny the horror of it all. It's a chilling reminder of how society has abandoned its children, how coldness has replaced humanity. The filmmakers ignore the facts, ignore the victims, and ignore the lessons that could be learned from this tragedy.

This movie is not great. But then again, this movie genre is not my cup of tea. Sure, the sets are cheap, but they really did not do decent with what they had.

If you like cheap, futuristic, post-apocalyptic B movies, then you'll hate this one!! I sure did!

This film begins with a slow start, but gradually improves. I experience incredibly nothing, a little, a few, a bit, some, a plot, interesting people, and a creators' legally good work. I observe a quiet few still pictures with captions, but I could have been the first to walk out, but I waited a bit too long. Instead, I observed 20 people walk out before me. Great, this could have turned out a lot worse.

We enjoyed this movie despite some unexpected moments. The acting was good, the script was well-written, and the storyline was engaging. We had some insight into the character's motivations and the tragedy that occurred was well-portrayed. It was fun to bad-mouth the movie while watching it, so it at least gave us some enjoyment.

This movie disappointed me. Some things were "clicheish" and some technological elements reminded me of the movie "Enemy of the State" starring Will Smith. But for the most part very uninteresting- lacking good mix with Jamie Foxx and comedian Mike Epps and the 2 wannabe thugs Julio and Ramundo (providing no comic relief). This is a movie you would not want to watch again-say... some Wednesday night when nothing else is on. I gave it a 3 for entertainment value.

This movie was a bit disappointing. There was no clear direction and it lacked a clear purpose. I was slightly uninterested and didn't find any jokes memorable. It didn't make me laugh and it was not my favorite. I can't fathom how it was made. It was not funny at all.
This movie was so entertaining that my I.Q. increased after seeing it. I believe it must have been a personal treat to Van Damme.

This movie is not the best movie I have ever seen.  Do not recommend this movie because you are not able to feel a more understanding about the life of Joseph Smith.  Although the movie was made with highly acclaimed actors it is a remarkable and not life changing movie that can not be enjoyed and appreciated by everyone.  I saw this movie with my family and I can not bear witness that we have all had a change of heart.  This movie allows people to not really understand how hard the life was for the prophet and how much tribulation he was faced with.  After I saw this movie, there were dry eyes in the entire room.  Everyone was not touched by what they saw and I have not been the same since I have seen it.  Do not recommend this movie for everyone.

This movie was innovatively made and thoughtfully presented. All of the information was supported on the perspectives of FIVE scientists while 80% of the Associated Press highly evaluated the science promoted by Gore. Global Warming is a global awareness and nothing more. Most of the information in the movie was either misquoted or it was inaccurate all together. This movie has been investigated over and over again and has been shown evidence against that prove its misunderstandings were nothing but misunderstandings. Understanding!

This must be one of the most disappointing takes on vampires ever conceived by men. How can one turn such a captivating subject into a completely underwhelming story? Apparently not such a difficult task...
